text:
Cheryl:

Are we in a good place to begin paperwork to bring Jen Davis up here on TDY in October?

If so, I would recommend we ask her to report on October 29 and I will get the EX office to start the paperwork. She will be detailed to us for 90 days, which will enable her to receive funding for housing, meals + incidentals, etc., and this 90 day period will carry her through the end of the term on January 20, 2013. This schedule would give me 10 days or so of consultation before a desired departure for Vienna on November 14.

I am not intent on rushing out to Vienna; the closer we get the more there is to be done, and we may not get ourselves "packed out" before we depart (not a wholly unwelcomed outcome, since we can set aside that task for December or January). But, if the elements are in place, Carol and I would like to go out mid-November in order to participate in IAEA meetings on November 26-30.

My swearing-in ceremony is scheduled for November 9 at 10am on the 8th floor. Whatever plan we embrace, that date is set and Carol and I are eager for the day.

Our friend, General Joe Ballard owns The Ravens Group. Our friend, General Johnnie Wilson, is on Ballard's board... They do extraordinary work across govt agencies including full management of Walter Reid, administrative work at NIH and management of facilities at the VA. They also do GSA work and DoD work... They carry all desired statuses such as Service Connected Disabled Veteran, minority, etc...

The Ravens Group has a consistent and strong track record in government services.

I've sought to have the Gens meet Under Secretary Kennedy. I don't know if my requests have made it to him... We know of specific opportunities State is seeking and we know that there are some timely opportunities, too.

You will see below some lower level work outreach that has taken place at State... But there are more opportunities than just those mentioned below...

I'd love the opportunity for our Gens to come in for appropriate meetings, which seems to be Under Secretary Kennedy. I think, while lower level outreach is going on, having this top level meeting would be invaluable for State to know and be aware of a govt contracting group with the best possible scores, results, status and cost saving measures...

I know Gens Ballard and Wilson would greatly appreciate your consideration in helping them share their work and meet the right folks.

Thanks so much. B.

Sent from my Verizon Wireless BlackBerry

Outstanding news! Miki Rakic called about 10 minutes ago to pass along that Goran Hadzic was arrested this morning in the Frushka Gora region of Vojvodina. He is on his way to Belgrade now for questioning, etc. Should appear before the War Crimes Court and be on his way to The Hague within 4-5 days. Tadic is giving a press conference at 11am. We will follow up with Miki and BIA to get additional details as soon as we can. Will also keep an eye out for any Brammertz statement.

I recommend a welcoming statement from the Secretary and the WH, if at all possible, noting the significance of this arrest for finally closing the chapter on Serbia's obligations to the Tribunal.

Mary Burce Warlick

Ambassador US Embassy, Belgrade +381-11-306-4605

Responding to separate emails from Uzra + Jeff:

1) Sinirlioglu delighted D/B will participate on Thursday, and has agreed to push official start time back to 14:30 to accommodate D/B wheels down ca. 13:00.

2) I told him I understood that BOTH Burns + Feltman will participate. (If the new news that D/B will participate means that Feltman will opt out, please advise).

3) Delegations requested limited to principal + 2, but MFA will adjust for us if we request. Please let me know our desired participant list.

4) Venue is Conrad Hotel. 5) FYI: AL SYG will participate.

Francis J. Ricciardone US Ambassador Ankara, Turkey tel: +90 312 457 7280

Guy from Mexico is in NY and is cooperating. Discussions with him continue this am. Since he is cooperating, no move to court or to presentment scheduled yet.

Mexican support has been excellent throughout. Alice has call sheet for Espinosa — call can take place whenever it's convenient for you later this morning (Espinosa is apparently out on West Coast, but Ops could confirm time difference).

Holding off for now on other calls that rest of us would make (Saudis, et al), pending further developments in NY.

Will let you know as soon as we have more.

For Secretary Clinton

Dear Hillary,

You will remember our initiative to bring the most senior retired generals from the Chinese and US militaries. With these 10 generals from the two countires, I am going to be in DC on October 21 and 22. these Generals have been part our of our Sanya Initiative - the unofficial mil-mil dialogue I started last year. It'll be me, Joe Prueher, Charley Wilhelm, Ron Fogleman, and Denny Reimer. The Chinese will be led by General Xiong Guangkai and include four other very senior and respected Generals from the PLA.

The Chinese view this as a formal track one program and take it very seriously. We will meet with ADM Mullen and ADM Keating in Honolulu and see GEN Cartwright at the Pentagon. It would be a terrific sign of the U.S.'s support for this relationship if you were able join or host (I'd be pleased to fund) a very private dinner on the evening of the 21 or the 22nd of October. Just you, the Generals, and interpreters - perhaps the Chinese Ambassador if you think that would be valuable.

I met with Kurt Campbell last month, and we will meet with him and Jim Steinberg. He expressed strong support for this dialogue as well as the economic one we started in Beijing last August. You know we would welcome involvement from State at any of our projects - our goal is to make a small but meaningful difference in the relationship.

Warm best wishes, (I'm cheering for you!)

I'm sure you saw Raj's speech last week; I thought it was courageous, powerful, and compelling. (I had my usual strong reaction to the absence of almost any mention of State, but on the other hand I've been hearing from some USAID folks that Raj is being criticized in the development community for being a State puppet, so I'm guessing he was trying deliberately to assert himself. Still, I'll be sending a strong message to him and Don and Susan Reichle on this point before I leave.) See below for Raj's follow-up — it's highly ironic, of course, but nevertheless strong and good stuff. I also wanted to note that USAID is already presenting a new face around town; Jose Fernandez and I were on a QDDR panel at CFR two weeks ago with Michael Kremer— having Michael be the USAID representative simply speaks volumes for their ability to be a thought leader and real player in the development community, as does Steve as their chief economist. Michael also made a strong case for what Development Innovation Ventures is already doing — handing out grants and expanding fellows. And the new monitoring and evaluation framework is attracting attention already from DFID. AM

Cheryl,

I received word from the White House, over the holiday, that I have been appointed Alternate Observer to the International Fund for Ireland with Dan Hynes of Chicago as Observer. I want to convey my sincerest thanks to you for your help in shepherding my nomination through the White House and ask you to thank Secretary Clinton for me. Secretary Clinton has always been an ardent supporter of the Fund and I doubt it would have survived without her advocacy. I am very excited about my appointment and look forward greatly to working with Mr. Hynes to promote prosperity on my native beleaguered island.

With renewed thanks.

Stella

Stella O'Leary President Irish American Democrats (202) 362-9064

wvvw.inshamencandemocrats.org

Cheryl:

Again, I'm so glad you asked. The Bureau -- whose leadership has suffered in the past -- must have an Assistant Secretary who is dynamic, knows the workings of government and the field of humanitarianism, and enjoys the Secretary's confidence. It is so critical, because, more than perhaps any other place in the Department, the Bureau is where so many of the operational objectives of the Secretary in QDDR are playing out, day-in and day-out — with dozens of refugee officers overseas coordinating closely with PRM and regional bureaus in Washington. There are several stellar individuals. This is a first cut, and I hope you'll give me the chance to come in with others if I think of more. How great it would be to have someone in place when I leave.

Any of these would be top choices. If you want me to rank them, best to do by phone. But on a 1 — 10 scale, they are all about a 9. Eric

Rich---Thanks for all you did to make the past year a successful one, I hope you and your family will have a happy and healthy new year. I'm looking forward to 2010!

Here's some questions and I'm copying Jake so he can help w the followup--

Right before I left, Kirsten Gillibrand called to discuss her cybersecurity bill. She wants to draft it so it favors State. I told her we would connect her up w the right person who would call her to discuss in the new year. Who should that be in your shop or elsewhere? Pis let me know so I can call and tell her.

When I was in Kabul, the Aga Khan told me he had given a "roadmap" to stability in Afghanistan and wanted me to see it. That's all I know; can you track it down?

Colleagues,

I am proud to announce the launch of the inaugural Civilian Security Tradecraft course at FSI. It is part of institutionalizing the Secretary's leadership and vision as laid out in the QDDR. The course will help prepare our foreign and civil service officers with the tools for strengthening civilian security abroad. I ask you to share this with your colleagues and encourage interested staff to enroll. Additional information is below, and a hearty thanks to the J family and to FSI for all their excellent work.

Best, Maria

Under Secretary of State for Civilian Security, Democracy and Human Rights Department of State 2201 CSI. NW Room 7261 Washington DC 20520 202 - 647-6240

The expression "do more" repeated incessantly in today's press is essentially a negative characterization of the Secretary's position. In general, it is code for "After so much cost and so many losses and so many bombs in our cities, the Americans are telling us we're still not doing enough." This negative interpretation is used by the PakMil to convince Pakistanis that the U.S. is a malign influence and to avoid taking the steps we seek.

When you brief her this morning suggest the following:

We avoid literally using the words "do more;" but Do not hesitate to specify what we want them to do; and Let's push back on this view: We acknowledge their contributions and their losses — and we are helping. Wewould never ask Pakistan to do more alone —we are doing more, too, including supporting Pakistan militarily and economically. Freedom requires constant vigilance and democracy is never "done."

Kern-Ann hit our top-lines as scripted to kick off our presser at the Reagan building, then used our affirmative messaging points to address the questions (which were along lines we predicted — see below). We are posting the video on our website and pushing out the transcript. The meeting itself was orderly and uneventful, ending about 15 minutes later than scheduled. Turnout was not that big considering all the press attention.

Issues Kern-Ann addressed in response to Qs:

We are now monitoring press reporting and will engage as needed to shapellorrect/fix. PBS is due to air the segment today which includes KAJ's interview done in Nebraska and we'll have to see whether KAJ's push back with NYT helped with the Cardno-Entrix piece they are working (which could run tomorrow).

KAJ/Caitlin — feel free to add/correct. KAJ endured a tough moot but we think it really paid off. Thanks to Caitlin once again for her super human efforts on this all week. Go team!

P/E colleagues:

If you haven't already done so, please view or read this week the Secretary's speech on economic statecraft, found at http://video.state.gov/en/tor)stories/video/1218722127001/economic-statecraft/s-creationDate/0-1/?0 . It is an important articulation of strategy and priorities sometimes under-attended in traditional DOS deployment.

The speech confirms the wisdom of our efforts here to increase commercial diplomacy activity, integrate economic/commercial staff from different agencies into one team, and begin evaluating ourselves - including in the formal officer performance review process - according to how well these priorities are advanced. As you know, Goals No. 1 & 3 of the Mission New Zealand MSRP and Goal No. 2 of the Mission Samoa MSRP articulate this subject matter as a top priority. Michele / Peter:

In the speech, the Secretary mentions sending out updated instructions on economic statecraft. If we have not already received that document, could you obtain a copy for us.

Thanks much. -D

Dear Madame Secretary,

Thank you. It has been a wonderful experience to travel with you and see you in action!!

The WE America event was terrific. It lift the hopes of so many women. Your example and your attention to on the ground change is clearly having an effect. It is inspriring to see.

Your restraint and steadiness with the Congressional delegation was quite extraodinary. I thought it brilliant to point out that Brazil can use the "cuba" card to solidify its support in the region. Rumors are that some did hear the points you made. Sadly, they may forget them on the plane back!!

I am eagerly working on the education and skills develoment initiative. Much is already being done.., as Walmart's contribution made clear. I want to make sure that we are providing the education to create a pipeline of scientists, engineers and not simply skimming the top. The Summit helped to crystalize the challenge and the chance to meet partners who could make this work.

All the best in Brazil, Belgium and Paris.

Kathleen

Huma, H met Asha at CGI and raised concerns about her security. She sent Asha to undersecretary Carson. They met for an hour. Note to US embassy in Nairobi was to be sent re Asha and her family's security. Embassy won't meet with her.

Today's massacre killed her closest allies and blinded and critically wounded her brother.

Asha is last moderate leader. She is speaking out.

They want to kill her, Huma.

Please tell Hillary.

If you want I will email her.

Asha's phone

Dick Wilbur at US Mission to UN in Geneva tried to contact embassy in Nairobi by email. No response yet.

Thanks, Allida Sent from my Verizon Wireless BlackBerry

Sorry for the tardy reply, but I've fallen way behind on nearly everything while I hurtle around the world on my one woman mission to convey American leadership and influence.

I think you know by now that we are working through this idea which has both positives and negatives, and I appreciate your concerns since I am, as you know, a devoted real book person.

Speaking of which, are you in town this week and weekend? If I'm here, I will try to stop by P&P Saturday or Sunday. Plans are still in flux, but seems likely. All the best, H

I sent lanny a draft of diplomacy chapter to see how Dal is likely to respond to inter-agency piece. I thought you would like his response. Tim Rieser was also surprisingly complimentary on Friday -- saying that he had seen many of these exercises but that this was the most thorough and thoughtful of them all.

"Thank you so much for sending me this; I am deeply grateful, and honored, to have the opportunity to comment. Let me begin by saying that, even apart from DOJ's interests in the QDDR, I think that this is a very impressive document; it is beautifully written, and compellingly argued."

AM

Dear Secretary Clinton,

Although I regretfully missed seeing you on your swing through Beijing earlier this year, I will be back in Washington on July 30. Would love the opportunity to meet with you briefly and give you up update on my thoughts/ insights into China and the rest of the region. The story is not quite as neat as it appears on the surface. Despite all the hype, this region remains an export machine that should struggle in the aftermath of the crisis -- with important implications for many of the global economic issues you are facing. I have had extensive meetings throughout the region over the past few months and would welcome the opportunity to provide you with a first hand assessment.

One other note: I will be publishing a book in Sept! Oct, "The Next Asia", which digs beneath the surface of many of the macro issues the region faces. It is generally constructive on the Asian outlook but lays out a number of critical milestones that must be hit to validate the hopes and dreams of the "Asia Century." I have asked the publisher (Wiley) to send you an advance copy of the manuscript in the hope you or your staff might find it of interest.

Hope to hear back from you on the feasibility of meeting later this month.

Best regards,

Stephen S. Roach Chairman Morgan Stanley Asia Phone:

NOTICE: If received in error, please destroy, and notify sender. Sender does not intend to waive confidentiality or privilege. Use of this email is prohibited when received in error. We may monitor and store emails to the extent permitted by applicable law.

I'm off to Seattle for a conf on development and women at Microsoft and mtgs with Gates, etc. I wanted to tell you that for your trip to Russia, we have an announcement for you to Gov of St Petersburg who is the highest ranking female official in the Russian govt. When I saw her some months ago, she went on at length about her respect for you and her meeting with you when you were Senator (she also met you at the Rejkavik W conf in '98) We are going to hold a US-Russia women leaders Summit in St P in april. It is in response to what I heard over and over during my trip earlier this year that there is a strong desire (and need) to engage with US. Women and the women's issues have been mostly off the agenda since the days we made it such a priority in the 90's and there is considerable recidivism. She should be happy about the proposed summit.

Secondly, when you meet with the Lithuanian FM this week, he will invite you to the community of Democ ministerial (end for Lith presidency) and as part of it a women and democ. Conf that will mark 10 years since the last one that was held in the continuum you started. There are so many different needs today.

Have a good trip.

Hi Cindy!

How are you? I hope all is well.

I have just returned from a series of field trips to the DRC, South Sudan, Rwanda, Kenya and Burundi - busy developing strategies for our new Cash and Voucher approaches.

You will be pleased to hear that in very many of the countries people I met spoke to me about the important need to address the first 1,000 days of life. I was very pleasantly surprised to hear reference to 1,000 days in some of the most peripheral areas and most difficult humanitarian environments. The countries were I visited had such high levels of accurate malnutrition, and I hope that they can really make progress in addressing the issue.

I remembered the summer of 2010 and I thought to myself that I must write to you and let you know that there is definite impact on the ground.

You mentioned the new arrival here. Yes, I am very excited to see the new direction—WFP is a very exciting organisation with so much promise. I hope we will see you in Rome one of these days too!

All the best,

Simon

Simon Clements Programme Officer (Field Support – ODJ & ODN) ODXC - Cash-for-Change Service UN World Food Programme

Office: Mobile FoodSat: 1301 - 2436

Dear Capricia,

As time moves on, I realize I haven't seen you and Mrs. Clinton (Hillary) in a long time, but I think of you both often. I don't know if movie producers are still worthy in your world, but next time you're in NYC I'd love to see you.

I have such fond memories of you guys watching SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE. I made another movie you might like about the ascendancy of King George after Edward abdicated, it's called KINGS SPEECH. The movie brings to light something that many people don't know, which is that King George was a stutterer and he hired an actor to try and help him overcome it. It's a fun movie that is much in the tradition of SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE, again I think you would both like it (and Hillary would approve because it's PG-13 with not too many swear words).

If you have any trips coming up I'd love to send it to you so you guys can watch and give me your opinion. I could also include a copy of THE TILLMAN STORY, that one is obviously not a happy film, but it's an incredibly important one.

PS

Your bad friend, Harvey PS — Please share this with Madame Secretary.

As I indicated in our Thursday am briefing of S, much to her skepticism I am sure, italy seems to be improving -- although serious risks remain. Below is Amb Thorne's latest reporting:

After Wednesday Italy moved, Berlusconi offered resignation, Napolitano accelerated approval of austerity measures and formation of new govt. Formal resignation and appointment of Mario Monti due Sunday night. Lot of political bickering going on but general direction fixed. Cast of new characters may change.

Merkle and Sarkosy have also chimed in. Spreads down off the peak but still very high. Italy knows what it has to do. David

I hope Thorne is right -- that italy knows what it has to do. We shall see if Monte can get along with the fractious politicians and can keep the public with him. He is very smart -- but his political and motivational skills will be tested. Bob

Burns, On the case where we represent the survivors and families for the embassy bombings, we just learned that the lobbyist for Southern Sudan is negotiating with the state department on a deal that would destroy these victims of the ability to collect money from Sudan. If you remember, last year after putting on a weeks worth of expert testimony the District court in DC gave us a judgment finding that Sudan was directly responsible for supporting and helping the terrorist who carried it out. We were hoping that the State dept would help us just like they required Libya to pay the victims of all of its terrorist acts before they were granted "restored relations" in 08. I know that there may be more important national interest involved but supporting the State Dept employees and their families who sacrificed so much should at least be one of them. I'll be coming to DC next week but can come up anytime. John

(SBU) Following up Margaret's meeting with Egyptian FM Aboul-Gheit, I called Hossam Zaki (per the Secretary's request) to ask again about Bill Burn's potential travel. Hossam said that it is a "solid no." No reason for S to push, no reason for VPOTUS to call Soliman, no reason to ask again right now. He was full of compliments for Bill Burns and assured me that Bill would be welcome at another time, "maybe ten days or so." But not now, "no way." His reasons were varied but mirrored those provided by Aboul-Gheit to Margaret. He also noted that Egypt has turned down Ashton and a number of Europeans. I noted that we have had inquiries from Congress about travel, and he said that Congressional travel would also not be welcome now.

Jeffrey Feltman

Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State

Cheryl, Thank you for your facilitation of today's meeting and for what was, at least from my perspective, a very useful conversation. Would appreciate your conveying the following note to the Secretary. Thanks very much. Wendy

Dear Madam Secretary,

Thank you very much for taking some of your very precious time to talk with me this afternoon. From my perspective, I found it a very useful conversation to better understand the challenges in front of you and the Department, daunting as they are. I appreciated as well the candor and sensitivity of the private discussion, a frankness that is essential to ensuring you get the best outcome to help solve problems and meet the needs of the country. I hope you felt you got direct responses from me and a better idea of capabilities and understandings that I bring to the table. I look forward to the further conversations you suggested and any other steps needed as part of your decision-making. And, as always, I am committed to supporting you whether in or out of government.

Thank you again, Wendy

We attempted to raise the issue of women's participation in the Iraq government, in their economy and more broadly when Biden was just in Baghdad. Jeff Feltman was trying to get it into the conversations there.

You will recall the comments of the Iraqi who participated in the NGO meeting with you in Doha about how the door has been closed to women in the government. We have had many discussions with impressive Iraqi women over the last couple years, and to a person they describe their fate as worse now than years ago. Yet without them it will be even harder for Iraq to move forward. To that end, we have been working with post on a action plan along the lines of the National Action Plan on women, peace and security, you will launch next week.

I hope you will find a way to raise the "women's issue" in your discussions tom'w.

As you wish. You just need to understand that I can explain to the press corps that I work with every day why I am not in Azerbaijan. It is about diplomacy and not headlines. It is very difficult to explain why the State Department spokesman is not present at a direct negotiation between the Palestinians and the Israelis, one of the administration's highest priorities and an event at which there will be a significant number of media. Whether we have a lot to say or a little to say, this will be a global media event and the State Department spokesman will not be there. I do understand our strategy, that we are going to keep our words sparse, given the sensitivity of the negotiations. And to one journalist from the paper of record who said he assumed I would be on the trip. When I hesitated and said I was not sure and then explained that we were making a deliberate calculation regarding our PD strategy, he then remarked that this means the media will have a painful four days in the region because the assumption is there will be nothing provided them. This undermines the trip and ultimately the Secretary. I am a team player and will remain a team player, but this is a decision that comes with a cost, including my credibility as the spokesman.

Pi

Lunch yesterday was a true treat; I will keep my menu as a lovely souvenir. Alexander was thrilled that you remembered his chinchilla! I truly look forward to working with you on some legacy speeches, and will start by sending some notes shortly on the ideas we discussed re Munich. I am truly frustrated that I cannot be there; Senator McCain invited me today to be part of his delegation but I am committed to give a speech in Denver. I've also turned up a few new ideas re Iran that I will send along this weekend. All best, and many thanks again, AM

Anne-Marie Slaughter

Bert G. Kerstetter '66 University Professor of Politics and International Affairs Princeton University 440 Robertson Hall Princeton, NJ 08544

Assistant: Terry Murphy tmurph_y

Website: www.princeton.edui—slaughtr

Hillary,

As you have been so kind to share your advice and mentorship with me in the past, I was hoping that we might find some time to chat about some of my current thinking.

With the fabulous results of the Presidents' re-election, I am privileged to be able to continue to serve at the CFTC. I recall your prior advice upon my being offered the post and it was invaluable. The challenges and opportunities to bring about common sense financial reforms have been fabulous. We are now moving beyond agency rule writing and helping the swaps markets transition to a new era of transparency and oversight. (The CFTC just completed final determinations such that the US has met the Pittsburgh G-20 commitment deadline of December 2012 to have our swaps clearing mandate fully in place.)

If we might be able to find a moment to chat, I would love to share my thoughts on possible new challenges and opportunities within the Administration.

I hope all is well with you as well as you gear up for this holiday time and a much deserved break from the day to day stresses of your current post.

Gary

This morning Majority Leader Reid convened an hour-long Senate leadership meeting to discuss the path forward on health care reform. Particpating were Senators Baucus, Dodd, Harkin, Durbin, Schumer and Murray.

Afterwards, Harkin and Durbin confirmed what has been suspected for a while - Senate Leadership has decided to go the reconciliation route on health care reform. The House, they said, will first pass the Senate bill after Senate leaders demonstrate to House leadership that they have the votes to pass reconciliation in the Senate.

Miguel E. Rodriguez

Deputy Assistant Secretary for Senate Affairs

Bureau of Legislative Affairs

U.S. Department of State

Huma, I wanted to relay to you the sincere sentiments of appreciation expressed by the PM's Office and the MFA for the very personal touch by the Secretary notifying the PM about postponement of the trip. Not lost on the GPNG is the fact that the entire trip was postponed, not the PNG portion. As you can imagine that is politically very significant.

Naturally, we stand ready to reconstitute the program or enhance it should the trip move forward at a later date. We got luck today w/the weather—not a rain cloud in sight.

Safe travels, and hopefully we will work together at a later date. Best of luck with the Haiti recovery effort! Regards,

Teddy B. Taylor Ambassador Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands and The Republic of Vanuatu tel: 675 321-1455 fax: 675 321-3423

Jake,

I wanted to update you on two aspects of our work leading up to the September session at the UN Human Rights Council where the U.S. will be a full member for the first time: 1) freedom of expression (addressed in this email) and 2) human rights strategy at the UN (in a second email on high side).

First, I'd like to let you know about the successful next step in a strategy we are pursuing at the UN Human Rights Council to begin to change the dialogue on Freedom of Expression. We think we have developed a well-balanced text that we can move forward to adoption in the UN HRC's September session. This work contributes to our long-term effort to improve this UN body. Progress on this issue would help us later as we address the even more difficult issue of the "defamation of religions" about which the Secretary expressed interest in a Monday senior staff meeting.

An 10-DRL-L-NEA group has been working together to implement the strategy that involves reaching agreement with the Egyptians on a text that we will roll out late next week with countries in the OIC (Organization of the Islamic Conference) and the WEOG (Western European and Other Group, our regional group at the UN).

Experts in L, DRL, 10, and NEA agree that the text protects all USG red lines and offers us a workable compromise that can secure genuine cross-regional consensus when presented in the Human Rights Council in September, hopefully avoiding a divisive vote on this issue. US and Egyptian teams also agreed to the possibility of further cooperation in the UNGA to come to a soft landing on defamation of religions if Cairo and Washington first succeed in passing the FoE resolution by OIC/WEOG consensus.

The latest regarding border issues:

a) Per EmbOff, border at Jimani remained disorganized but functional as in recent days.

b) The flow of persons across the border is constant, but no mass influx. However, official figures under-report the numbers of people crossing, as the data reflect only those being processed correctly. Some Haitians are sneaking across the border, per USG official. Haitian media also report "tens of thousands" leaving Port-auPrince, some for the DR border. However, police officials say they have not seen increased illegal entry attempts in the mountains around the Jimani crossing.

c) A Haitian immigration official said that as of lpm on 1/19 he had issued approximately 600 laissez-passes to travelers without documents. Dominican authorities at the other side of the border crossing are generally turning away travelers without a valid visa or official travel document. Medical emergency cases continue being allowed in.

d) The border crossing at Jimani was closed for 45 minutes after the Haitian colonel in charge of customs on the Haitian side began demanding "manifests" from vehicles trying to bring assistance across. GODR officials managed to talk the colonel into backing down, but plan to seek his removal. (Note: It is unclear whether this was an attempt at rent-seeking by the Haitian official, but some reporting implied that. End Note).

e) As the next Market Day in Jimani will be Thursday, efforts are already underway to see if market activities that day can be organized so as not to block/hamper through-put of assistance / evacuation vehicles.

Happy New Year to you, too! I'm sorry for the delay in getting back to you.

On menu: As a start, I can make a list of the lunches that he's made so far. Jason is given money advances. I'm not positive of the total for last year since I came in April but I can have that answer for you by morning. I have skim milk for you.

On the Human Rights Watch Report: I found it online and will print. It is 96 pages so I can put this in a binder if you'd like.

Parks and Recreation: NBC Thursdays at 8:30pm The Good Wife: CBS Tuesdays at lOpm

And it is a huge honor to work for you. I learn so much every day and I am so grateful for this unforgettable experience. Thank you!

HELP-- we are now waiting for at least an hour to take off--and maybe longer

I am so unhappy since again no one said a word but as soon as we pulled away from gate we were told we'd wait for 20 minutes and now just told it will be at least an hour but the good news is that they can't keep us out here longer than 3 hours! So, I want to go to plan B--pls do all you can to get us flying and if that doesn't work, I want to drive so have asked Service and DS to try to work that out.

Please Pass to the Secretary

Madame Secretary,

A shoot out occurred on August 20 in front of the American School in Monterrey (AFSM), resulting in the death of two bodyguards. An investigation is continuing into the details, but our understanding at this point is that it was an attempted kidnapping targeting the relatives of a local business executive. While it does not appear that U.S. families were targeted, the sharp increase in kidnapping incidents in the Monterrey area, and this event in particular, present a very high risk to the families of U.S. citizens who might be become incidental victims.

U.S. security and law enforcement personnel have engaged local and federal security officials to seek their help on understanding the immediate risks and measures that can be taken. I have urged U.S. families at the Consulate in Monterrey not to send their children to school in the coming days while we review the events that took place on August 20. We also are advising U.S. citizens in the area that we have urged Consulate personnel not to send their children to school while we complete this security review.

I am sure that the warden notice will lead to a rash of press reports on U.S. concerns about security in Monterrey. More broadly, if the government cannot get the kidnappings in Monterrey under control, that may affect our ability to function in Monterrey. I have advised Secretary Espinosa of this, and have sought her help as well to address consulate security.

Consulate personnel are currently on "authorized departure" and have the option to send their families to a U.S. location. Pat Kennedy is in close touch on these matters.

Carlos Pascual

I promised you I'd let you know the very moment I had made a decision on the Humphrey School.

And in what has been the most difficult career decision I have ever confronted, I have decided to accept their offer. It was so difficult because I cannot imagine a more meaningful and fulfilling position than the one I now hold. And I cannot imagine a more inspiring leader than the Secretary — or more support than that which I've received from you, and from others on her senior-level team.

I've always believed deeply that how one leaves a job is as important as how one executes his or her responsibilities while on the job, and I'm committed to ensuring that my transition does not impair the Department's humanitarian (or QDDR) work. Just spoke with Ambassador Yasser Othman, the Egyptian rep in Ramallah. He said that yesterday evening, the Egyptians "got a message from Israeli NSA Amidror, who said that if Hamas is ready to establish a new calm,

Israel is ready to discuss the matter." He noted that Egypt (didn't specify, but presumably EGIS) had spoken with someone in Hamas' Gaza political leadership this morning, who stated that Hamas "does not want to blow up the whole situation ... there need to be red lines beyond which no one progresses, so we are able to ultimately contain the situation and return back to the position from which we started." Othman reiterated that the Egyptians are having great difficulty in reaching contacts from Hamas' military wing, "as they've all gone underground, and are not picking up their phones." He also noted that "there is a sentiment of profound fury within Hamas over al-Ja'bari's killing, it will be very hard to convince them to return to calm this time."

Othman said that Cairo is nonetheless actively trying to calm the situation, urging Hamas leadership to get things under control, as "it is not in Egypt's interest for the situation to deteriorate, as the more it does, the harder it will be for our leadership to contain the mood in Egypt." He underscored that "Egypt is doing its part to try to restrain Hamas, and the U.S. needs to do its part to restrain Israel."

Othman said the Egyptians decided yesterday evening to open Rafah 24 hours a day for passenger traffic.

writing the argument on 2011 is this: "The absence of a timeframe for transition would deny us any sense of urgency in working with the Afghan government. It must be clear that Afghans will have to take responsibility for their security, and that America has no interest in fighting an endless war."

You will have to stress among other things:

That summer 2011 is the start of a transition, the pace and nature of which will be driven by conditions on the ground.

That our resolve is reflected in a tripling of troops since Obama took office, and a significant civilian commitment that will continue after our combat forces leave.

That we aren't just going to let the Taliban sit around and wait -- we are surging in Afghanistan to take the fight to them and redoubling our efforts with the Pakistanis to squeeze the other side of the border.

That July 2011 is enough time for our training effort to start bearing real fruit, for our troops to make serious progress in creating space for the Afghan government, and for our civilian efforts to have meaningful impact in Kabul and in the field.

Paris, January 19, 2010

COMMUNIQUE

During their telephone conversation last week, the President of the Republic and President Obama expressed the resolute commitment of our two countries in Haiti, and decided to combine their efforts in order to deal with the urgent humanitarian situation and to respond, in the future, to the enormous reconstruction requirements.

As you'll all recall, in early July the organizers of World Pride presented an award to Secretary Clinton for her work on LGBT human rights globally. S accepted the award via video and Political MC Toby Bradley gave a personal acceptance speech as well.

On top of the award, an American artist made the attached flag in honor of the Secretary. It's a take on the American Flag and has the words of her speech in Geneva sewn in to the flag. Those countries where same-sex relations are criminalized appear as "dark hole" stars, those where criminalization laws have been removed appear as white stars. As countries decriminalize, the dark holes become white stars. There are a lot more details (Clinton and Eleanor Roosevelt's silhouettes, for instance) that make this work of art a really impressive piece.

It is currently hanging in the entrance lobby at Embassy London and is having a dramatic impact there. The hope is that S will be able to be photographed with it hanging there at some point. Further discussions are ongoing about how best to use this artwork, and where is might eventually land (museum, Clinton Library, Art in the Embassy program, etc...).

Happy to talk more about this, if folks have ideas or interest.

Thanks, Ken

Just met with Walter Isaacson to discuss next steps in terms of developing a comprehensive strategy for addressing the issues you raised at yesterday's meeting. We are putting together a small team from State and BBG to provide market analysis and help guide a strategic planning process. I'm sure you've already seen this story in the NYT. I just wanted to say that I am very sorry that it has played out as it has.

http://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/27/world/americas/27mexico.html? r=1&ref=world

It is unfortunate that the press focus has been on failed states. I would have hoped the stories would have focused on the work that I have done the past three years leading the Foreign Policy program at Brookings and directing a major international project on global governance that has called for bringing Mexico, Brazil, China, India and South Africa into new institutional arrangements for global governance. In the study we stress that none of the major transnational challenges of the day — from the economic crisis to climate change — can be solved without engaging the world's emerging economies, starting with Mexico, and giving them an equal seat at the table in an expanded G8.

The other key theme is the work I have done in bringing together "government-wide" initiatives to work in partnership with other countries. One cannot treat drugs, immigration, energy and international politics in separate cones. Rather, they affect each other, and our foreign policy needs to integrate these interconnected elements into a coherent strategy that produces results. The point is that we want to work with our international partners in ways that address their realties — and not let policy be derived from our bureaucratic structures.

I understand that the situation with Mexico is complicated. I am ready to help in whatever way I can to produce the most productive outcome.

Carlos

Hello and Happy New Year Jim,

Friends of WFP has decided to provide its annual "Leadership in the Fight Against Hunger" Award to Secretary Clinton this year. The award is presented at a ceremony on Capitol Hill (within one of the House/Senate caucus rooms). Approximately 200 people attend the event including Members of Congress, NGO representatives, business leaders, administration officials and other leaders in the fight against hunger.

As you know, Friends of WFP is a non-profit organization dedicated to addressing global hunger. Its board members include former agriculture secretary Dan Glickman, former Senators George McGovern and Bob Dole, YUM Brands CEO David Novak, former NSC Advisor Sandy Berger and others. I established the organization in 1997.

Before officially announcing Secretary Clinton as this year's award recipient, we hoped to confirm that Secretary Clinton will be available to personally accept the award. We plan to schedule the award ceremony in September on either a Tuesday or Wednesday evening (at approximately 6:30/7pm). We would select the specific date based on Secretary Clinton's schedule.

I think the ceremony would provide another good opportunity to shine a spotlight on the unprecedented commitment of Secretary Clinton and President Obama to addressing global hunger. Thank you for your help in engaging the appropriate officials in the State Department.

All the Best, Rick Leach

Dear Cheryl,

Next week the GAVI Alliance will ask donors to commit $3.7 billion to immunize an additional 4 million children by 2015. Now, as GAVI prepares for its next decade of progress under new leadership, is an opportune moment to examine critical challenges and how they can be addressed to ensure continued success. This policy brief, GAVI'S Future: Steps to Build Strategic Leadership, Financial Sustainability, and Better Partnerships, was developed collaboratively by the CSIS Global Health Policy Center and the Center for Global Development. The brief provides analysis and recommendations to GAVI leadership in three vital issue areas: GAVI's mandate and business model; its financing strategy; and the GAVI Secretariat and partners' capacities.

Its many achievements notwithstanding, GAVI will need a strengthened, strategic approach to meet future demands. In the midst of a global recession and constrained donor and national budgets, and as the vaccine landscape expands and becomes more complex, GAVI will need to concentrate on its core mission, extend coverage to the underserved in low-income countries, plan strategically for the future, better tie health systems investments to vaccine gains, and test whether GAVI can contribute to assisting lower-middle-income countries accelerate their immunizations. It is essential that GAVI's financing efforts shape markets to reduce vaccine pricing, at the same time that GAVI aggressively leverages traditional donors, wins over emerging economies, and increases partner government commitments. The GAVI Secretariat can and should do more to maximize its partnerships with UNICEF, the World Bank, and WHO, and GAVI will benefit significantly from much stronger branding, communications, and high-level outreach and representation.

Click here to read the full brief: http://smartglobalhealth.org/GAVI

Madame Secretary,

I wanted to send you a short note about today's release of the new Global Burden of Disease study and how it relates to cookstoves. The study estimates that 4 million people die each year from exposure to cookstove smoke — that's twice as many people as we thought (2 million). The study now ranks this as the 4th worst health risk factor in the world (we used to say it was 5th worst in developing countries), after only high blood pressure, smoking, and alcohol use. And it is the 2nd worst health risk factor in the world for women and girls, after only high blood pressure. Exposure to cookstove smoke is the single worst health risk factor in South Asia for both sexes, and the 2nd worst health risk factor in SubSaharan Africa (though first for women in most parts of SSA). This 4 million figure is more than the study attributes to HIV/AIDS, TB, and malaria combined.

But the most shocking statistic of all is that only a handful of people are working full-time to solve this severe risk factor: 15 staff at the Alliance, Jacob and a few other U.S. federal employees, a few staff in different U.N. agencies, a handful of bilaterally-funded efforts, and scattered researchers, businesses and NG0s.

Thank you for your leadership on this issue to bring the Alliance where it is today. Today, we know better than ever before that our efforts have been well directed.

I hope you are feeling better.

Best, Kris

Hi! Hope you all are getting some R&R as the summer wanes.

Your Africa trip has generated a lot of visibility and momentum on women's issues. I wanted to follow up on an idea we discussed, when we met a few months ago, for raising the profile of women's issues and creating a unique platform for you in the U.S.

You may recall that Melanne and I were developing ideas for holding events to connect people working on women's issues around the world, and to raise the visibility of the issues in the US.

Whitney Williams has joined us to flesh out a vision for a series of conferences that would bring together policymakers and experts from the field with women you have met around the world - and people at the grassroots level in this country.

Each conference would be followed by a special event featuring musical, cultural and culinary celebrities (yep, celebrity chefs) from the U.S. and other countries to generate visibility online and in the entertainment media, which would reach a lot more people than the policy conference alone.

These events would create connections among people who often work in isolation, and generate ideas for improving policies and practices. They'd also inspire and engage a whole new generation to get involved in global women's issues.

Jake,

Jeremy said you took note of the Islamist protests and asked for an assessment. Here's my quick take.-Andrew

Islamist forces do not command nation-wide support and probably do not represent a direct political threat to the TNC, but their advanced battlefield experience and access to weaponry could pose a significant military challenge.

• The Islamists are not particularly popular outside of certain areas of eastern Libya. Sallabi and his followers are as vilified as Jibril in much of the country. Indeed, many of the political groups that oppose Jibril, such as those centered in Misrata, view the Islamists with equal, if not, more hostility.

• Both Islamist and secular militias have operated with relative restraint so far. With Sirte and Bani Walid still in regime hands and Qadhafi on the loose, there is enough of a rationale to support continued cooperation.

• However, once operations against Qadhafi and the regime are wrapped up, this force for unity is likely to dissipate. It is at this point that militias, including the Islamists, will probably abandon caution and pursue a more aggressive campaign for power, perhaps including violence.

Even though the Islamists may not be able to displace the INC. Jibril and his allies suffer from a serious credibility problem. If the INC fails to make strides in giving other political movements (in Tripoli, Misrata, Zintan, and elsewhere) a real role in governance, it may find itself without a viable national political base.

Our beloved 67th Secretary of State has departed the building for the final time in her tenure. After almost a million miles, thousands of bilats, meetings and phone calls, hundreds of pre-briefs, camera sprays, press avails, photo ops, pullasides, clutches, huddles, and drop-bys, not to mention the scores of interviews and townterviews (I have never liked that word!) receptions and dinners, HRC's time here at State has come to an end.

Madame Secretary, From my perch just outside your office I have had quite a view of history in the making and it has been a distinct honor and privilege. Your entire State Department family in Washington and at all of our embassies and consulates around the world have been inspired by your unrelenting passion, dedication, sense of duty and mind boggling stamina!

You will be missed here at the Ship of State and you will always be remembered with the greatest of respect, admiration and affection.

Thank you, thank you, thank you for everything you have done for us, for our country and for so many around the world.

As they say in the Navy, we will always have your six and we wish you only Fair Winds and Following Seas!

Get some rest!

I'm no expert on Israeli politics, but the exit polls are interesting.

As Dan noted in an email to some, the big news is a poorer than expected (but still leading) showing for Bibi, a surprise surge for Lapid, Bennett not so hot after all, and Kadima has fallen off the map. Tzipi's new party is polling 7 seats.

Emerging bottom line: Bibi could do a 61 seat right/right coalition if he can work with Bennett and Shas. Razor thin but fewer parties to juggle and more ideologically cohesive. Or he could go up to 69 in a limited center-right coalition (with the traditional religious parties but not Bennett, and only Lapid from the center.)

So, while the comparatively poor showing for Bibi's coalition looks to be a sign of weakness, the basic coalition options are still the same as expected but a firmer center partner in Lapid IF that's what he's looking for. Remember he has always said, anyway, he favors the broadest possible government.

And, if the center had formed an electoral coalition —and polled the same results they did separately — they would have outperformed Likud/Beiteinu and at least in theory have had the right to try to form a government. Remember that, when you hear laments that the Israeli public is forever more stuck in the right lane. (But then of course also remember that today's center looks reactionary compared to the center of 20-30 years ago.)

And finally, remember the budget issues — a problem with Shas among others —will loom large in coalition calculations.

David

Chris Hensman U.S. Department of State W: 202.647.9130 I M:

Increasing outreach

I was more than a bit annoyed when I heard that at a recent daily meeting, when, in commenting on the success of your web-chat with young Egyptians, you asked why we did not do more of these and someone responded that they were glad to hear they had "permission" to do them. As I know you know, I have been pushing people to do this for some time and have made it quite clear that no permission is required.

Since prodding doesn't seem to work I now plan to "direct" each regional bureau to work with PA to develop a plan for weekly web-chats focused on issues of regional relevance and engaging the full range of DC based FSO's and subject matter experts, including those with language skills suited to each region. We invest an enormous amount in training our officers and this will help leverage that investment. This isn't brain surgery and can be done quite simply and efficiently if people put their minds to it.

In an effort to appeal to their enlightened self-interests I also plan to tell them that I will be providing you with a detailed report on this initiative.

My apologies for not having been able to get this going sooner.

They did a background briefing at the White House today for columnists and opinion makers. Paul Jones participated. Here are two questions -- and the answers given -- that I wanted to call to your attention:

Will the withdrawal be conditions-based or begin automatically?

Summer 2011 is a strategic inflection point.

We are guaranteeing a U.S. troop level for a certain period of time. That is 18 months from now. The situation will change, and so we will naturally reassess where things stand.

Our emphasis is on building capacity so that the Afghans can assume natural ownership of their own security. We plan to begin to remove our combat troops as we transfer responsibility to the Afghans.

The pace of the withdrawal will be based on an assessment of conditions

NOTE: The assumption seems to be that the transfer process will be a district by district effort, and that there will surely be at least one district where we can transfer by summer 2011.

What are the revised endstates and training timelines for ANSF?

Erica, Sam, Jake:

The Africa Bureau has taken the following steps in the past three hours to win support for the Libya vote in the UN Security Council.

Nigeria

We attempted to reach Foreign Minister Ajumogobia, but Embassy Abuja informed us he is in transit in Asia and was unavailable. Our Chargé reached out to Nigerian MFA Permanent Secretary Uhomoibhi, the number two at the Foreign Ministry and President Jonathan's point-man for UN Security Council coordination. Uhomoibhi hedged ultimately but said his government would decide its position at the highest levels and expressed hope that the decision would be the "right one."

South Africa

I reached out to South Africa's National Security Special Advisor to Zuma Welile Nhlapo, detailed the four parts of the draft resolution, and underscored the importance of standing up for liberty and democracy in Libya and pressuring Qaddafi to forestall further violent retribution against people seeking greater freedom. Although it was well after midnight in Pretoria, Nhlapo pledged to pass the message to colleagues working the issue. I underscored the urgency.

Separately, PDAS Yamamoto discussed our outreach strategy with Ambassador Gips in Pretoria, who told us that Minister of the Department of International Relations and Cooperation Mashabane could not be easily reached, as she was at the airport seeing off Aristide;

The South African Embassy in New York told USUN, we understand, that South Africa would vote with us. Regards, Johnnie Ambassador Johnnie Carson Assistant Secretary for African Affairs

German ambassador Koch phoned at 5pm, said that Westerwelle had reached Khar. Ten minute call, cordial.

W made the pitch: that the international community has been trying to ensure that Pakistan's interests are represented as we work out the future of Afghanistan. It would be a shame if, at this moment, Pakistan would take itself away from the table.

K said she agreed. She said that during the Defense Committee meeting yesterday, the military had pressed hard for her to announce that she would not go to Bonn, but that she had been able to prevent that [somewhat more forward leaning than when I talked to her]. But she was not sure she could sustain that argument in the days ahead.

Ambassador Koch said that the best we could say was that the door is still open, and we need to keep it open as long as we can. We agreed that with a cabinet meeting Tuesday and a parliamentary session coming this week sometime, keeping the door open will not be easy. But we should continue to press the Pakistanis to come to Bonn.

Cameron

I am in India but wanted to quickly weigh in on the prospects of a Japan stop next week after Europe. I well recognize how brutal the travel schedule has been and have been reluctant to add to that given pressing current circumstances in Libya and elsewhere.

However I believe the Secretary should consider going to Japan for a brief stop next week to do several things: underscore our commitment to Japan and manifest it with more publicity for all we are doing; indicate that we will launch a public private recovery effort; subtly counteract preoccupation worries; meet crisis team in government; thank embassy and military relief team; meet some of the displaced; and speak publicly to the Japanese people.

We can do this in one day and have an historic impact, quite seriously given the stakes and gravity of the situation. Happy to develop a schedule to support this effort if warranted. Best Kurt

Marc, Tom, Doug, Ambassador, and Colleagues:

The negotiating session lasted two hours 20 minutes in the formal conference room of the Cabinet. Secretary of Defense and Cabinet Secretary Nargis Sethi led the Pakistan side of 14, including Secretary of Finance Wajid Rana, and representatives of MOD, GHQ Federal Board of Revenue, Customs, et. al. From the beginning, there was a spirit of good will, compromise, and let's-get-it-done. In opening remarks, I emphasized that we want an agreement for mutual benefit.

We closed on the MOU language except for one sentence directly related to the negative list. We made excellent progress on the negative list, although both sides will need to consult their experts and lawyers on just a few points. We also took some time on the Terms of Reference and made good progress there, too. We agreed we will follow up with a small-group experts' meeting on Monday afternoon.

At the end of the negotiating session, I noted that cargo is still not moving, despite the Pakistani interagency meeting two days ago that cleared 1579 pieces of cargo to move. I said we have a growing perception problem, and urged the Pakistani side to get things moving ASAP. Secretary Sethi fully understood the point and said she would follow up appropriately.

In closing, both sides emphasized the spirit of cooperation and our commitment to come to closure soonest so that we can clear the final document on both sides and then sign.

The invaluable Elizabeth Hoffman is providing a fuller readout and will also send back details on the few remaining questions that need further clarification.

Dick

As I mentioned yesterday, fm steinmeier asked to speak with you. He said he's available to speak today either between 11:30 and 12:30 or 4-5pm. Below is purpose of call. Also sending you separate news story.

Purpose of Call: FM Steinmeier has asked to speak with you to request your intervention in the deal to sell 55 percent of General Motors' (GM) holdings in the troubled German car-maker, Opel.

We understand the significance of this issue for German industry and German workers. Treasury is the lead agency on this issue, and has been in close contact with your Chancellery and the Ministry of the Economy.

• Our government is taking a "hands off' role. Any decision will be made independently by GM, based on commercial considerations. The United States government does not play an active role nor do we have a position on any particular bid.

Background: An independent trust comprised of representatives of GM and the German government has been weighing bids from several interested parties on a controlling interest in GM's holdings in Opel. The German government has come out strongly in favor of a bid by Canadian Auto Parts Manufacturer Magna and has financing contingent on acceptance of Magna's bid. GM has concerns about this offer. Steinmeier was an early supporter of Magna's bid and came out early in the media to show leadership in protecting German jobs. Chancellor Merkel has since co-opted the issue and has thrown the full weight of the German government behind Magna. In May, Steinmeier spoke to you by phone about possible U.S. support for GM and the repercussions for Opel.

Statement by the Secretary

The Death of Polish President Kaczynski and His Delegation

I join President Obama in offering my deepest condolences to the people of Poland, to the Kaczynski family, and to the families of all those killed in this tragedy. Lost alongside President Kaczynski and his wife were Polish leaders from across the political spectrum, men and women who shaped and sped Poland's post-1989 democratic transformation and were leading Poland into its promising future. The tragedy of these lives cut short will be felt deeply across the world, but their legacy will live on in a free and flourishing Poland.

The United States stands with the Polish people in this difficult hour. Like the country he led, President Kaczynski was one of America's most valued and trusted allies. He was well known in the United States as a champion for democracy against an oppressive regime, a man whose journey took him from the Gdatisk Shipyards to the presidency of a free people. President Kaczynski was an unstinting advocate for freedom and human rights not just in Poland, but around the world. He will be long remembered and sorely missed.

The Polish people have endured more than their share of sorrow, but they have always shown resilience and resolve in the face of adversity -- and I know they will pull- together in solidarity to grieve this loss.

My thoughts and prayers are with all the people of Poland today.

I just got off the phone with President Fernandez. His efforts to dissuade Zelaya and Company from traveling tomorrow have not been successful. He was very worried about what would happen, and requested our help in ensuring that no incidents take place at the airport.

I told him I shared his concern. I summarized for him our efforts to date, and told him that nascent engagement with the armed forces and the de facto government would collapse if Zelaya tried to force the issue tomorrow. I told him of the Cardinal's plea to Zelaya to not return. He said the Cardinal in Santo Domingo is close to the Honduran Cardinal, and said he would reach out to him. I encouraged this. I told him that I thought the elements of a deal were on the table, we just needed to find a way to get everyone to sit at the table and start talking. I told President Fernandez that he could play an important role in creating a climate of confidence, and suggested that he reach out to interested parties like Ricardo Maduro and others inside of Honduras. He said he would do so and get back to me

Cheryl and I discussed how to do an effective strategy session. Monday early afternoon is the first clear shot we have at getting the right group of people in the room together for an extended period of time.

We propose to start the discussion from the following premise: We've addressed, in one fashion or another, to one degree of satisfaction or another, most of the major items we set out at the beginning of last near. We've moved the needle, but we haven't changed the game. Now the question is, what are the major milestones over the next 12-18 months? What should we be aiming at? And especially, what are some potential game-changers — moves that would shift the global landscape in meaningful and long-lasting ways?

Everything will be on the table — regional issues, transnational issues, etc. Everyone should read the book of look-ahead papers; identify things they think we should pursue; and add ideas — especially creative and far-reaching ideas — on top of what's contained in them.

We propose the following roster:

Jim Jack Bill AMS Derek CDM Jake Rich Kurt Judith Harold

Let us know what you think.

Jake

One of our Mexican staff and the husbands of two Mexican employees were killed last night in Juarez.

Dear Jack, Anne-Marie and Jim:

Without prejudice to the deliberative process now underway, I owe you my unvarnished and very frank views on the QDDR process -- and how the U.S. Government must best organize itself to anticipate and respond effectively to crisis and conflicts. The stakes are huge, and because we are at the point where the working group I co-chair on this issue has to generate recommendations, this is the time for me to offer some basic perspectives directly to you -informed by my experiences working on these issues at the NSC, at State, at the United Nations and in the NGO community, as well as writing and teaching about them over the course of the last decade. The QDDR process itself has also impacted my perspectives and, more importantly, raised serious concerns for me about mistakes we must avoid.

I also realize that current bureaucratic and political realities may impose limitations (or compel adjustments) to the kinds of organizational arrangements we might make. But the starting point for me is what makes the most sense.

My propositions:

Best, Eric

• Nominations for Egypt's presidency will open in April, Egypt's newly-appointed Minister of State for Parliamentary Affairs, Mohamed Attia, has revealed.

• The constituent assembly that will be elected by the parliament will draft the country's new constitution within a month, before subjecting it to a public referendum, Attia said in statements quoted by state-run Al-Ahram on Sunday.

• Presidential elections will by organized following the constitutional referendum, the minister said. A constitutional declaration issued by (SCAF) in March stipulates that the new parliament will elect a 100strong assembly to draft the constitution. Attia explained that the constituent assembly will be formed in a joint meeting by both houses of parliament after the end of the parliamentary polls.

• In an interview with satellite channel Al-Arabiya, aired on Thursday, the head of the advisory council, Mansour Hassan, said Egypt has experts who can draft a constitution within one week. Hassan told the channel that if the constitution is not concluded on time, presidential elections will be held as scheduled, and the SCAF will hand over power on the first of July. (AMAY)

• All local media also announced today that SCAF has officially issued a decree to hold the Shura Council elections on two phases only instead of three. Phase one will be held on Jan. 29 and 30 and phase two on Feb. 14 and 15.

We initialled the text of an Open Skies Agreement with Japan at about 10 tonight. I owe enormous thanks to so many of you for a true team victory. From Secretary Clinton on the seventh floor to my tireless secretary in EEB, Tucker Richmond Stewart, we pulled together to make a bit of aviation history and, much more important, to do something good for our consumers, communities, and national economy.

I was able to contact the offices of about ten key Senators and Members of Congress before the signing, with a focus on those who, with a strong Delta presence at home, had expressed concerns about proceeding. I stressed that we'd negotiated provisions that offer Delta assurances of fairness and the potential to grow. I also emphasized that the decision to proceed was taken only after careful consideration at very senior levels of State, DOT, and White House.

Thanks, again, to all for your support.

John Byerly

Madame Ambassador, dear Capricia,

Having returned from another unforgettable trip within the Experience America program, I would like to thank you and the 17 protocol officers who accompanied us on the trip to Arkansas wholeheartedly for a truly special experience.

I said to Larry Luxner that the trip should be headlined "Experience the Unexpected".

I so much appreciated our group being hosted at the Clinton Presidential Center. I loved to see the beautiful countryside on our bus trip from Little Rock to Fayetteville. I may have been the only member of our group to see The March of the Ducks at the Peabody Hotel across the Street from our hotel in Little Rock. I was deeply impressed by the number of Fortune 100 companies that have a significant presence in Arkansas. I have found my new favorite painting at the breathtakingly beautiful Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art: Rosie the Riveter by Norman Rockwell. I will never forget meeting two of the Little Rock Nine.

You all did such a wonderful job in organizing the trip meticulously, paying attention to every small detail, enable us to have encounters that we ourselves would not even have thought of and, most of all, you were patient, gracious and untiring in making this a unique trip for all of us.

Thank you so very much!

Warmly,

Republicans are overjoyed. Democrats are tearing out their hair. Twitter may explode.

A couple thoughts and some perspective:

1) The latest Gallup poll covers the dates of Oct. 11-Oct. 17 which means it is only capturing one day of post-debate sentiment. We won't have a full post-debate sample until Tuesday (Oct. 16-22). I will leave it to Gary to explain any other details about polling methodology etc.

2) There is an expectation by many that the race will tighten back up next week, thanks in part to an expected boost in Democratic enthusiasm.

3) That said, if Romney retains a lead in this poll — or any other airworthy poll, it suggests that Romney's big win in Denver and his solid performance at Hofstra helped him to finally clear the "acceptability" bar with those wavering Obama 2008 voters he needs to win over. The Romney campaign has long held that this race will resemble 1980 where the race remained very close until the very end when it broke dramatically in Reagan's favor. Like Romney, Regan's big break came from a solid debate performance. However, the political polarization in this country is much more intense and solidified than it was in 1980.

Madam Secretary — As expected, Senator Reid moved today (11/15) to amend the pending Energy and Water appropriations bill to add our bill plus the Financial Services bill to create the second "minibus" appropriations package. Senators Menendez, Nelson, Rubio all objected to the motion because of language allowing bank to bank transactions between Cuba and the United States contained in the Financial Services bill.

Senator Reid then offered a modified motion that removed the Cuba language. Senators Moran (KS) and Vitter both objected. Moran because he supports the Cuba bank transfer language and Vitter because of Mexico City policy, UNFPA and what he described as language permitting abortion on demand in Washington DC.

Senator Reid then proceeded to fill the amendment tree on the underlying Energy and Water bill, essentially freezing action on the Senate floor until some sort of agreement is reached on the universe of amendments to be considered. That agreement could encompass amendments to our bill or simply to Energy and Water. So we are in a holding pattern until Senators figures out how they would like to go forward.

Senator Reid has made it clear that he intends to complete the conference report on the first "minibus" which contains the CR through December 16th as well as the Defense authorization bill before adjourning for Thanksgiving and has already threatened to keep the Senate in through the weekend and into early next week.

Dave

This reform will likely be criticized by some who think that putting more money in the hands of local actors will expose USAID's programs to more risk. But this is precisely the point; only by supporting local change agents—both inside and outside developing country governments—can we actually strengthen the hands of people in poor countries who are working to change their own societies for the better. That means managing risk wisely, rather than trying to avoid it altogether. And in our field research, 36 of the 39 activists we interviewed said they want USAID to support their government's directly, because it would make it easier for them to hold their governments accountable and prevent corruption.

What does all this mean? It means better aid, aid that strengthens the capacity of reformers in poor countries. And for the millions of people across the world who have been demanding these reforms, USAID has shown it is actively listening.

Sincerely,

The Aid Effectiveness Team

Below are my notes on Dennis' 14 points, which involve 6 parallel steps each and then #13 and 14 are combined, joint action by the two sides.

*ISRAEL* 1. Israel should offer voluntary compensation to settlers to leave the West Bank. (NB not unilateral, part of orchestrated interaction) 2. Build housing now within Israel to show you don't intend permanent occupation. 3. Only build future settlement housing within the blocs - not beyond them. 4. Open Area C to economic activity for Pals. Just 120k pals live there, but -- alongside Jewish settlements-- all the rock quarries are there, and Pals have no access. 5. Increase Palestinian police presence in Area B, and increase their areas of responsibility. 6. Work out security criteria to limit incursions into Area A.

*PALS* 7. Put Israel on their maps 8. Acknowledge historic Jewish connection to the land and to Jerusalem. 9. Stop incitement / de-legitimization. (No more hiding behind local officials on this). 10. Condition your public for peace. (ie returning to Arafat's "peace of the brave" rhetoric). 11. Start building permanent housing in camps for refugees. 12. Make major investments in rule of law/anti-corruption efforts.

*BOTH*

13, 14. Youth on both sides should have an exchange of classrooms. Create a forum for kids to be together. "Dialogue of the deaf" right now.

Below are the results of the 2nd round:

African Group (1 seat available) • Mauritania 72 • Togo 119

Eastern European Group (1 seat available) • Azerbaijan 90 • Slovenia 97

Bottom line: results inconclusive. Since none received the required two-thirds vote of members present, voting and submitting valid ballots (which is varying in each vote), the General Assembly is immediately proceeding to a third round of voting. The third round is again restricted to the above countries.

If the third round is inconclusive, the fourth round (and 5th and 6th) will be an "unrestricted" round, whereby votes may be cast for any eligible Member from the respective regions, including those that were part of the first round but not part of 2nd or 3rd rounds, i.e. Hungary could get some votes.

Voting for third round has occurred, ballots are being collected, and the General Assembly will soon be in recess again to count the votes.

Dan

As they committed during Indian Commerce Minister Sharma's visit earlier this month and projected as far back as Minister Fahim's September 2011 visit to India, Pakistan's cabinet approved a new negative list with India today (before the end of February).

The new negative list of 1209 restricted product lines (of about 6800 tradeable categories) replaces the previous positive list of about 1900 allowable product lines. This more than doubling of tradeable goods roughly meets my expectations but may be a disappointment given the wild hopes of some in New Delhi, especially given that the negative list rejected by cabinet two weeks ago included only 636 products. The late additions reflect last minute pressure from the autoparts, machinery, and textiles industries. Implementation is set to occur within one month, and the goal is still to phase out the list by end 2012 and to announce Most Favored Nation status at that point. (Comment: Though I am skeptical that they will be able to move that fast given the political calendar and industry pressures. Other countries,

including India, maintain a limited sensitive list and are considered technically WTO. compliant.)

This is real and historic progress for Indo-Pakistan relations, a big victory for Zardari's government, and a real achievement for the New Silk Road vision.

James C. Schwemlein Office of the Special Representative for Afghanistan & Pakistan
