This may be a crazy idea, but as far as we can tell we need ideas. Suppose we launched a "Pledge for Palestine" campaign that copies Warren Buffet's "The Giving Pledge" campaign, described below — he's trying to get 40 billionaires to give away most of their money. I had asked some S/P folks to think about how we might take that campaign global to help change the attitudes of elites in places like Pakistan and Latin America, but perhaps Warren Buffet could be convinced to lend his name — or perhaps Michael Bloomberg or Danny Abraham (together with a very wealthy Muslim) to a similar Pledge for Palestine campaign. Such a campaign among billionaires/multi-millionaires around the world would reflect a strong vote of confidence in the building of a Palestinian state and could offset the ending of the moratorium for Palestinians (there would also be a certain shaming effect re Israelis, who would be building settlements in the face of a pledge for peace). With even 30 calls to the right people in the Clinton fundraising network it should be possible to generate a substantial enough amount quickly enough to capture the public imagination on the heels of the President's speech and, critically, to serve as an expression of global solidarity with the Palestinians and but also a meaningful promise of material improvements for Palestinians on the West Bank. That could significantly bolster Abbas in a way that could help him stay in the talks. This is what diplomacy beyond the state should mean.

A brief description of the Buffett campaign is below; a longer description with the people Buffett has approached is attached.

AM

Hillary,

Sorry to bug you about this, but I learned today in a book industry bldg about State's partnership with Amazon for Kindles for embassies. I am sure there are great benefits to this program, but someday (maybe soon?) I'd love to chat with you about why this news is so distressing to independent booksellers across the country. Brad and I appreciate very deeply that you are a stalwart and steadfast champion of stores like Politics & Prose and all that they represent to their communities and to promoting an informed and engaged citizenry. But right now, Indies are in a battle for survival due in large part to the monopolistic and predatory business practices of Amazon and the uneven playing field on which we are forced to compete. I can't convey the scope and depth of this issue -- or the emotion attached to it -- in one email. But I really hope we can discuss it sometime.

On a related note, let me know when you're ready for some more book suggestions. Did you ever read God's Hotel, the book that Becky edited by the doctor working at Laguna Honda in SF? It's a must read for you. If you don't still have the galley, I'll send a hard copy over to you.

X0X0

Lissa

Pursuant to our conversation, it seems we have concurrence that we respond to the HFAC staff query (below) via telephone call which I would be pleased to make. (H also agrees it would be best to respond with a call.) Following are talking points for your review and approval:

• Secretary General Insulza's designation and announcement of Gov. Bill Richardson as a special envoy for the OAS was made without any consultation with or consent of the U.S. Mission to the OAS or the Department. In fact, we first heard of the announcement through press reports.

• Upon hearing the news, Ambassador Lomellin immediately raised concern with the Secretary General and expressed our displeasure, as he should have consulted with the USG before making this appointment. We specifically expressed concern that the Governor's views might be misconstrued as representing official U.S. policy, and in particular on the very sensitive issue of U.S.-Cuba policy. Insulza committed that it would not occur.

• Gov. Richardson is a private citizen and his views in no way represent U.S. foreign policy.

• We remain concerned with the implications of this designation in potentially misrepresenting the views of the , U.S. and the Organization of American States, and intend to raise the matter again with Insulza in light of Gov. Richardson's remarks at Brookings on U.S.-Cuba policy.

• It is not a paid position.

Please advise how you wish to proceed. Thanks.

Fernando

Fernando D. Rojas Alternate Representative U.S. Permanent Mission to the Organization of American States U.S. Department of State 2201 C Street, N.W. Washington, D.C. 20520 (202) 647-9482

Huma:

Happy New Year! As you board the plane and prepare to depart, please know that we are deeply grateful for the tremendous effort that you have made to allow the Secretary to participate in Brazil's historic inauguration.

The press here has focused intently on the Secretary's decision to participate, and has given prominent play to the statements that have come out of the White House and the Department describing the importance of our bilateral relationship. The Foreign Ministry and Dilma's transition team have given a very positive spin to the Secretary's role in the inauguration, and made clear that she is very welcome. Among the general public, the news has provoked a deep sigh of relief and is seen as evidence of our willingness to work with the new President and overcome the recent problems that have complicated our relationship.

When the Secretary arrives, she will also find a collection of heads of state looking to have a word with her. The format in PlanaIto will allow this to take place during the ceremony and immediately afterwards. In particular, Colombian President Santos has asked to speak with the Secretary. Also, last night the Peruvian ambassador told me that President Garcia will go to PlanaIto to speak with her. I am sure others will line up to greet her.

The Brazilians have worked hard to meet our logistical and security requirements, and the movements today should be smooth. Of course, if you can convince the pilots to fly fast and get here early it will be better for everyone.

Again, thanks for your great help. Your effort, and the Secretary's incredible stamina and willingness to go the extra mile (or extra 4,000 miles), will pay big dividends.

Regards, Tom

Dear Secretary Clinton, At your Deputies meeting earlier this week you asked about the status of the Enterprise Funds in Tunisia. I thought you would appreciate an update on OPIC's Franchise Facility for Tunisia, which OPIC initiated in response to your announcement that OPIC would provide $2 billion dollars for private investments in the Middle East and North Africa.

Since then, we have been working closely with the State Department, USAID, the Middle East Investment Initiative (MEII) and Shore Bank International (SBI), to establish a $50 million franchisee lending program in Tunisia. Last week, OPIC and USAID signed an MOU which will provide $1 million in grant assistance today and $4 million in subsequent years to cover operating expenses for MEII/SBI, OPIC's implementing partners in Tunis. Through MEII and SBI, OPIC will provide $50 mill in loan guarantees and technical assistance to local financial institutions, which will lend working capital to Tunisian franchisees interested in partnering with American, European and Tunisian franchisors. We will soon be disbursing to MEII/SBI for them to begin the diagnostics on the local banks for the facility.

As I have said about a number of recent projects, this facility would not have been possible without the keen support of the State Department and USAID, whose staff were a key part of getting this project done. This is yet another example to add to your list of U.S. development agencies combining forces quickly and effectively to advance the U.S. foreign policy and development agenda.

This facility will help small, local entrepreneurs bring new American franchises to Tunisia, and I am proud that OPIC, State and USAID have pulled this together after you called on us to support the MENA region.

Best,

Elizabeth

Elizabeth L. Littlefield President & CEO Overseas Private Investment Corporation

Israeli Ambassador Michael Oren called me today to complain about our comments today on the Jerusalem housing evictions. Saying that he was calling under instructions, he made comments on three basic themes:

1) The evictions of the Palestinians in Sheikh Jarrah were purely a legal matter. These were illegal squatters. The case went all through the Israeli court system and was decided by the Supreme Court. This was not a provocation. If there was a provocation, it was when the illegal squatters stopped paying their rent.

2) Israel objects to the suggestion that this was a violation of the roadmap. Israel requests clarification of what part of the roadmap obligations the U.S. believes were violated.

3) Israel rejects the suggestion that the timing was connected to the Fatah Party Congress. There is no connection.

I undertook to convey the demarche and made our response about how this really is unhelpful, especially at this time.

Jeffrey Feltman Acting Assistant Secretary Bureau of Near Eastern Affairs Department of State

I understand that plans are afoot to have EUR (Gordon) and SRMC (Pandith) lead the session on CVE at the Chiefs of Mission conference. We find this deeply problematic. S/CT has both the Department and interagency acknowledged lead on CVE. We have by far the most CVE activity going on at State, including a wide range of analytic and programmatic work. When it came to briefing the President on the Secretary's plan for Strategic Counterterrorism, a central component of which involves CVE, she asked me to do the presentation. We represent the Department regularly at the Tuesday WHSR meetings with the President, where we update him on, among other things, CVE; I am slated to be the deputy chair of the CSCC, which is perhaps the Department's foremost major CVE initiative this year.

S/CT has also spearheaded the effort to create a Department-wide CVE community of interest and convened the Administration's first interagency summit on the subject. In the context of our RSI meetings with posts in key regions, we have been working to motivate our ambassadors to innovate in this area. We have run three major international conferences in little more than a year on the subject. We are creating the Global Counterterrorism Forum, one of whose key working groups will be on CVE. Moreover, as I've discussed with both Cheryl and Jake, the transformation of S/CT from its current state to a full-fledged bureau, as envisioned in the QDDR, will center on the role we are developing in CVE and capacity building.

Dear Dr. Ballard:

We understand that the Government of Turkey has requested your assistance in the search for the Turkish Air Force RF-4 that was brought down off the coast of Syria on June 22.

As we have previously discussed, the United States supports the Turkish Government's determination to find its lost pilots and the wreckage of the Turkish aircraft. We wish to facilitate Turkish operations toward that purpose by any appropriate means. As Secretary Clinton said on June 24 we stand in solidarity with the Turkish people after the terrible loss of their pilots, and we lend our strong support to the Turkish government in this matter.

We recognize and respect that the EN Nautilus is a privately-owned and operated vessel registered outside the United States, and that its management will take its own decisions with respect to any contractual services it may undertake with the Government of Turkey. Nonetheless, we greatly appreciate your offer to the Government of Turkey to support its search operations.

Bill

Dear Melanne: As you know, President Sirleaf and Sec. Clinton are meeting on Friday morning of this week.

A key point which Ellen will propose is the creation of a US-Liberian Bi-national Commission to institutionalize the gains in Liberia and ensure that the partnership endures well beyond the present administrations in the US and in Liberia. Such a proposal would allow the priorities (from AFRICOM to food security, MCC) to be categorized, charted, reported on and measured for success.

The Commission would oblige regular meetings and require constant high-level US engagement. Other areas of common concern and shared responsibility such as governance, energy, regional security could be incorporated into such a framework.

The US-Nigerian Bi-national Commission inaugurated in 2010 by Sec. Clinton is a model for consideration.

Given the anticipated departure of Sec. Clinton from the State department, regardless of the outcome of the US election in November, we would trust she would be supportive of such a superstructure to preserve and protect Liberia's future.

The second point, I want to signal is that Ellen would like a few minutes alone with Hillary at the meeting. Many thanks, Debbie

Following five days of high-level talks in Addis Ababa, the Government of Sudan and the Sudan People's Liberation Movement agreed to temporary political and security arrangements for the disputed Abyei Area. Under the terms of the agreement, which was brokered by the African Union with high-level interventions by Secretary of State Clinton, Special Envoy for Sudan Princeton Lyman, and others, the armed forces of both sides will withdraw beyond the boundaries of Abyei and an interim security force composed of one brigade of Ethiopian forces will deploy to Abyei under UN auspices to provide security, facilitate humanitarian assistance, and protect civilians. The Agreement also establishes an Abyei Area Administration composed jointly of Ngoc Dinka and Missiriya. The Administrator will be an SPLM nominee, and the Deputy Administrator will be a GoS nominee. The parties are expected to sign the agreement tomorrow morning, with Ethiopian forces expected to deploy to Abyei on or about June 25.

Jeff believes it would be helpful. This is his assessment:

I've been in touch more or less continually with the Tunisian Ambassador here, who suddenly seems as though his own handcuffs have been at least loosened. He in turn is in touch with Morjane. I know they'd welcome a call. Their requests to us have to be handled carefully. They are trying to restore calm, which on the one hand is a good thing -- violent riots and looting aren't inherently good things, especially now that Ben All has left -- but on the other hand could be, if we're too aggressive, part of a campaign to establish "Ben Ali Lite." The "system" has an interest in self preservation (and I suspect Ben All left because the army and party bosses told him they were jettisoning him). We have an interest in opening up political space.

While the transfer of power to the Parliamentary Speaker puts the interim presidency in more of a gray bureaucrat cog in the system than the PM is, there is a real plus: it acknowledges Ben Ali ain't comin' back. (Constitutionally, the PM assumes the interim presidency for a temporary absence or incapacity, while the Speaker gets it for a permanent departure or incapacity.) We're working with Embassy Tunis on ideas. This is a real opportunity

Had dinner last night (Tuesday, February 16) with Joschka Fischer. We had an interesting conversation on Iran and Saudi Arabia, among other things. (As you know Fischer is now director of the Nabucco pipeline project.) On Iran, harsh, targeted sanctions are absolutely necessary, but are most effective diplomatically when always coupled with an offer to negotiate. The iron fist in the velvet glove approach achieves several objectives: According to Fischer's intelligence, Ahmanijehad wished some negotiated settlement but was blocked. The regime has splits at the top. Perhaps true, perhaps not. But constantly pushing negotiations alongside sanctions puts additional pressure on internal divisions, whatever they are. Extending an open hand while brandishing a stick closes diplomatic and political room to maneuver for Iran: Its refusal to accept the open hand justifies application of the stick. Even when sanctions are enforced it always remains useful to say another way is open. The damage done to Iran is therefore the result of its own choice. This approach also aids the opposition. A purely condign sanctions strategy can contribute to the regime's will to punish and tighten repression. Talking of regime change, of course, undermines the cause of regime change. It is a gift to the regime. The opposition is a new factor in the Iran equation that must be taken into account on the political and moral level. Pushed to the wall, the regime may feel compelled to repress, which might involve thousands or tens of thousands of political killings. On Saudi Arabia, Fischer points out that if Iran develops nuclear weaponry the Saudis already have their own bomb. The Saudis invested in Pakistan's nuclear weaponry partly for this eventuality; that's their bomb in reserve.

Dear Cheryl and Jake,

I wanted to let you know that after a great deal of soul-searching, I have decided to leave the State Department in about a month.

This was an exceptionally difficult decision; one of the most difficult I have made in my life. It has been a honor and a real joy to have been part of the team here at State; the past year has been one of the most enriching experiences of my career. I am leaving only for personal reasons; after pushing myself as hard as I possibly could the last several years, I need to do this for myself, to spend some time away from work with my family and friends and reenergize.

Thank you once again for the remarkable opportunity to serve our country and work for the Secretary. This has been a rare privilege, and I cannot stress enough how appreciative I am. I hold the entire team here in the highest possible regard.

Ganzoury made a strong pitch for support in his telcon with the Secretary, stating he needed $3-4 bn in order to stabilize the situation this month and provide the security that would make economic progress possible. The Secretary noted we had spoken directly to the IMF, with it imperative that the GOE invite the IMF team and consult with Egyptian stakeholders in advance. Ganzoury said he would be seeing the IMF in a few days (Note: has the IMF not communicated its delay?), but that a program would take a month to build and Egypt needed assistance immediately. He specifically asked whether the US had identified and frozen Mubarak/regime assets that could be tapped, noting that Gulf pledges of aid were not materializing.

The Secretary pointed to Gulf concerns over stability in Egypt and said real concerns were raised by the on-going violence. The images were deeply disturbing, particularly of the women being beaten. Ganzoury insisted he had issued strict instructions to the security forces "not to use even water," but also blamed the actions of thugs in creating the disorder; S re-emphasized the need for security sector reform. Ganzoury agreed with S on the need to accelerate compensation for victims.

In OSCE Sec Gen race, we have remained mostly on margins, noting only that we could support several of the candidates. Lithuanians now pressing for a stronger signal, now that former Austrian FM Ursula Plassnik has taken a clear lead in straw poll. Unless anyone feels strongly in other direction, I plan to let him know we can support Plassnik as the front-runner.

Plassnik is a strong personality and as a former FM might have some difficulty in accepting the limited powers of the Sec Gen position in a consensus-based organization dominated by participating states. But she's clearly smart and experienced, and has the full backing of most of the West Europeans (including, particularly, by Merkel who has lobbied us on her behalf.) She may ruffle some feathers in Vienna, but I don't think we should stand in the way of this train.

That said, there is a chance others (Turks, Russians, etc.) could block her — in which case we'd be fine supporting Italian diplomat Lamberto Zannier, who would probably be next on the list.

Let me know if any objections. Jake/Huma you might want to run by S as well.

Dear Team,

Thank you for your comments about what you would like said at the meeting with Secretary Clinton and Senator Graham. I will try to summarize them for you: first you want to express your appreciation for both her having such a meeting and also for defending religious freedom throughout the world. You also want to express the depth of commitment the faith community has to serving the neediest people in the world and give several examples of what you have done. Maybe most importantly you want to share that in order to work hand-in-hand with the government there needs to be mutual respect and an appreciation for differing religious beliefs, and that these beliefs should also be respected. Best, Shepherd

I am working on a paper for you on branding but thought I would give you a preview of my thinking while the formal recommendation works its way through the clearance process.

As you know the issue of branding continues to be a major challenge. Despite the fact that the USG spends billions of dollars each year administering a broad array of programs and initiatives, there is little recognition among foreign publics of the extent of our investments and assistance. There are literally hundreds of different logos and branding treatments across government departments and agencies with little or no reference to the United States. In many cases, specific branding requirements in contracts with our implementing partners are either waived or ignored. While it is relatively easy to identify the problem, finding a solution is difficult even within our own Department. There are probably a number of reasons for this --- everything from "institutional egos" to the need to focus on more Immediate priorities. Yet each day that passes without a resolution of this matter is a day we lose to promote our national interests.

I hope to have the paper to you for your consideration by the end of next week. In the meantime I'd be happy to answer any questions. jm

Public diplomacy efforts across Africa are not only helping us to amplify USG messages at this difficult time, but have actually helped roll back demonstrations and have had a tangible real-time positive effect on what's going on. In Khartoum, PAS contacted an IVLP alumnus and shared USG statements with him, leading him to convince the Muslim organization he is part of to call off a planned demonstration and to express support for the Secretary's statement. In Zanzibar, after the Embassy sent them a statement reiterating public comments by the White House and the Secretary and reiterating long-standing USG support for Tanzania, another Muslim group canceled its planned demonstration to show appreciation for the embassy's statement. The Somalia unit (based in Nairobi) received statements of support both from the new Somali government as well as Somali radio outlets, in response to Somali-language translations of S and POTUS statements. Across Africa, posts have been distributing and amplifying both S and POTUS remarks, using the most appropriate tools available : via social media, e-mailed statements, and by hand or by phone. These activities have born real and important results.

Madam Secretary,

I just gave Melanne Verveer a goodbye hug as she wrapped up her visit to Bangladesh and departed for Nepal. She worked great magic here connecting with Bangladeshis across the spectrum from ministers and Nobel Laureate Md. Yunus to Grameen borrowers and Grameen "walkers" (beggar women) whom she met when we visited a village to see Grameen in action. Her genuine warmth and respect for Bangladeshis electrified the villagers and, through expansive media coverage, the nation, as she brought the best of America to the people.

She also used the visit to great effect in delivering a clear message that America cares deeply about Grameen and wants to see Grameen effectiveness and integrity continue undiminished in bringing hope to millions of Bangladesh's most vulnerable, especially poor women. She urged timely selection of a new Grameen managing director who is renowned, respected, above reproach and who has deep passion for the Grameen philosophy. Her message was spot-on, and I am so grateful that she delivered it so effectively.

I assure you Mission Dhaka will arduously build on Melanne's legacy as we work hard and smart to get the government to ensure the next Grameen managing director is the right person to sustain the institution. I hope success in this regard will help create an environment conducive to your visiting Bangladesh, where I would want to take you to a village so you, too, can experience the Grameen magic at work.

All the best as the new year continues,

Dan Mozena Ambassador to Bangladesh

Per the plan, a statement is being released in your name. This is the same statement you saw in the memo package from Mitchell:

Today's announcement by the Government of Israel helps move forward toward resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. We believe that through good-faith negotiations the parties can mutually agree on an outcome which ends the conflict and reconciles the Palestinian goal of an independent and viable state based on the 1967 lines, with agreed swaps, and the Israeli goal of a Jewish state with secure and recognized borders that reflect subsequent developments and meet Israeli security requirements. Let me say to all the people of the region and world: our commitment to achieving a solution with two states living side by side in peace and security is unwavering.

:-( I knew you would say that! But of course I asked first - so I won't. So here is what I was going to write: 1. She is a hard worker - and people appreciate hard work. 2. She is a gracious person - the most important quality for a successful diplomat.

So now you are the only reader of these words! (Unless you change your mind).

So proud of you, Hillary - when President Clinton and I talked about my PBS column (I think I mentioned he called me, which was a great thing!), we both reflected on how great a Secretary of State - and person - you are.

Lanny

The Special Assistant to the Secretary of Defense

To set the record straight: our civilian surge efforts have been impressive and have met the commitment made by you and the President in the Afghanistan-Pakistan Strategy in March 2009 as well as his West Point Speech in December of 2009. As we committed, we have more than tripled our civilian numbers in Afghanistan — going from 320 personnel and barely 40 in the field in January, 2009, to 1134 interagency civilians with 407 of those personnel in the field as of May, 2011. In many cases, our civilians are operating in extremely dangerous situations right alongside the • military. Moreover, each year we recruit, train, and deploy a nearly complete replacement team — as the military does, only with a far smaller base of personnel.

I suggest you call David Ignatius sometime next week laying this out as well as the broader issue.

Tom

As we close up shop here in the Embassy's control room, here are final observations from our teams:

- Polls closed on time throughout the country, and counting began in an orderly fashion. Poll closing was more problematic in the Port-au-Prince area; some voting centers obeyed the 5pm extended closing but others did not. There were no reports of violence relating to closing of voting centers. OAS, CNO and other groups report the same overall satisfaction with the voting process.

- U.S. and Canada teams reported across-the-board results in favor of Michel Martelly. Obviously, this is just anecdotal, but so far we have Martelly leading 12,160 to Manigat's 3,311. Local press is beginning to report numbers in favor of Martelly in Port-au-Prince. International press is reporting smoother elections than November 28 and uncertainty regarding turnout. Mulct will make an official statement this evening, but it hasn't been released yet.

- OAS speculates turnout was around the same as November 28, perhaps a little higher because more people were able to find their polling places. It's impossible at this point to make any judgment about turnout.

We will have Embassy people at the CTV starting when it opens tomorrow at 6am.

Here are two great pictures to end the day — the first is of a woman voting, and the second is vote counts taking place.

Cheryl,

You had mentioned this morning that the Secretary was interested in the possible deployment of the Comfort to Chile. I asked my staff to check with WHA to see if this was something they were working. I'm told that because of the need to resupply the Comfort in Baltimore and consequent travel time, the concern is that it will not provide nearterm medical assistance. USAID/OFDA is supporting the deployment of the Air National Guard's Expeditionary Medical Support (EMEDS) unit, composed of 57-person medical team, six tents, and medical equipment and supplies to treat up to 3,000 patients. According to USAID/OFDA staff at U.S. Southern Command, the EMEDS will likely be located in BioBio Region, northwest of most-affected Concepcion city. The EMEDS is capable of providing laboratory, radiology, pharmacy, and dental services to affected individuals. In addition, the EMEDS has the long-term care capacity for up to 10 medical or surgical patients at a time.

Please let me know, however, if we need to press the Comfort option. Dan

Update on Ukraine Election Situation

With over 99.9 percent of the vote in Ukraine counted, Yanukovych leads by 3.5 percent (almost 900,000 votes) and is the clear winner and next president. The Central Election Commission should complete its vote tabulation today and must certify the results within ten days; certification is expected as early as Friday. Tymoshenko, who has been silent publicly, plans to bring cases of alleged electoral fraud to the courts, but they will not change the result. Tymoshenko claims that she intends to work within the law and not to incite street protests.

Our recommendation is EU Ambassadors in Kiev

have recommended the same approach to Brussels, but want to revisit it if there is no progress by Friday. Medvedev called Yanukovych today with praise for the conduct of elections, but stopped short of congratulating him on his victory.

Following certification of the election, Tymoshenko is likely to appeal within the legal five-day period. This will likely push back an inauguration date until early March.

I just received a call from Arias. He expressed his appreciation for everything the US had done in support of democracy in Honduras. He said the recent tough messages by Insulza, OAS Ambassadors and USG officials. strengthened by US sanctions, was having an impact on the M regime. He praised our decision to close the consulate and urged that we also move to take away tourist and business visas from key regime members and supporters. I told him we were working on implementing the visa and other measures which I expected could be announced soon.

Arias was critical of Z saying his recent public statements continued to be unhelpful. He described Z's statement advocating the death penalty (presumably to apply to his political enemies) and asking for the extension of his term in office as "disastrous". He said that Insulza had made the right call by not allowing Z to address the OASGA. We agreed the influence of FM Rodas over Z was highly negative,

I told Arias I would be back in Honduras tomorrow and planned in the coming days to press influential political, business and civil society and urge support for the immediate signing of the Si Accord. Arias and I agreed to stay in close touch in the coming days.

Hugo Llorens Ambassador U.S. Embassy Tegucigalpa

I'm sitting here in Haiti with Grace Nelson and Pam White and we're singing your praises. (Nan Ellen is here too). Pam was eager to do events to celebrate the difference women are making in Haiti.

It was 14 years ago almost to the day that I was here with you. The group of women from Haiti who were at VV/Uruguay conf. came to the ambassador's residence to tell you that you had so inspired them that they were forming a Haiti version of VV. I told everyone gathered at the residence tonight about that meeting which had taken place with you on the same spot where we were all gathered tonight.

The NGO is today the premier women's organization (and many were here tonight), They managed to get a 30 percent quota for women in govt passed and they now hold over 30 percent of the ministries, They are also the driving force for growing women-run SME's.

Grace was so excited to hear about the launch of the State Dept Artisans Alliance that she's going to come to the launch event on Tuesday at State. The Alliance will be housed at Aspen. You can't make the launch, but we have mention of it in your Business Council remarks and we'll have a few of the key leaders there for a photo at the end of the Council meeting.

Anyway, your inspiration continues to be very palpable here all these years later.

Hello Sung and Steve (from Beijing), As I promised Sung, I would weigh in once I got back to Beijing. The visit to the DPRK by John Lewis, Bob Carlin and me was a shocker. They took us to Yongbyon and showed us a functioning 2,000 centrifuge uranium enrichment plant in operation and a small LWR under construction. The technical implications are significant and you understand the political implications better than I do. I am attaching a quick-look summary of my technical observations. Bob Carlin will follow with policy observations based on our discussions with MFA officials and their implications as soon as he has a chance. I am scheduled to be in DC for an advisory function for Secretary Steve Chu on Monday, Nov. 22. I will attempt to see Secretary Clinton since my colleague, Bill Perry, had mentioned my trip to her during a recent West Coast swing. And, of course, I very much would like to brief the two of you. At this point, I hope that Bob Carlin and I will be able to get appointments either late on Monday, Nov. 22 or early on Tuesday, Nov. 23. We are all returning to San Francisco on Sunday. I will try to contact Sung from here and then again when I return to my Stanford office on Monday. Thanks, Sig

H: This may be worthless meandering on my part, but if the US unveils its own position in the new negotiations, inevitable if they are not to collapse, perhaps that position should incorporate at its heart what the Israeli government has already agreed to in the final status negotiations at Camp David, along, of course, with certain adjustments and amendments to account for the past ten years in terms of boundaries, etc. This puts the burden on Bibi to repudiate Barak in principles and details if he pushes back, splitting his coalition, and appearing to be the rejectionist. Also it makes the US seems utterly reasonable, for the Israelis have already agreed to the core of these positions and arguments cannot be made that they would undermine security, etc. Furthermore, three-quarters at least of US Jews supported the Camp David peace effort. S

Cheryl and Jake:

Reverend Jesse Jackson called me around 6 pm this evening (9/17) to provide a readout of his trip to Gambia to urge President Jammeh to stop the arbitrary execution of death row inmates. The visit appears to have been a success. Rev. Jackson said that President Jammeh agreed to an indefinite moratorium on further executions, and also agreed to release two Gambian-American citizens serving sentences of 20 years from a Gambian jail. According to our Embassy in Banjul, one of these Americans was convicted of allegedly participating in a coup plot, and the other was allegedly convicted of treason for printing pro-democracy T-shirts. Our Embassy also reports that President Jammeh agreed to release the two Americans provided they return directly to the United States with Rev. Jackson tomorrow. Our Embassy and Ambassador Ned Alford assisted Rev. Jackson and his delegation in Banjul, and are now working with Consular Affairs to expedite the departure of the released Americans. We did not sponsor this trip, but our Embassy provided the appropriate facilitative support — for which Rev. Jackson praised. Please pass to the Secretary as appropriate.

Johnnie

Second, people were REALLY moved by the last segment, three people even told me they teared up. I'm guessing and hoping you hear this directly from random folks in the coming days.

And I think because it's been a lousy couple of weeks for the Admin, with mixed messages and bad news, coupled with many people seeing you for the first time for an extended period talking about the job and your relationship with the President, and that combo was probably the most powerful reminder since your speech in Denver that you're in a class all your own (including the President who became enmeshed in the Gates incident)

That you didn't wait for the envoy question was key, you turned it into a strength. What you said about the President and how you said it, one can't help but think how much of a team player you are and how remarkably you've adapted to the role.

You were definitely on your game. You either threw a perfect game - or at least a no hitter. So this couldn't have gone better, achieved everything we needed to times 10, and comes on the heels of a great 10 days.

Will be interesting to see the storyline that emanates from this. Because there was no substantive news, it'll be a focus on style - especially saving Biden.

Hi Huma-If you are w/S would you pass her this note? Hopefully before she speaks to Senator Leahy? Thanks.

Madam Secretary-We have had a chance to review a draft of Senator Leahy's appropriations bill which is scheduled for mark-up on Wednesday. In addition to the higher levels of funding that that I've relayed previously, the Chairman is carrying language on a number of your priorities including:

Tunisia loan guarantee Egypt debt relief Enterprise fund authority for Egypt, Tunisia, Pakistan and. Jordan Continuation of phases 1&2 of pay comparability Increase in the cap for A/S positions Broad transfer authority inside of OCO Reauthorizing OPIC.

In short, the Chairman has been very good to us. I thought you should know that before you connect with him if you haven't already. Sorry for the informality. Dave

The Watergate building manager was getting complaints from tenants because the Libyan demonstrators were getting increasingly loud and boisterous and had been there several hours. The building manager called USSS who in turn called DS. Both responded to the Embassy.

The building manager intervened with the DS agent who responded that only the Embassy could have the group leave because they were in the Embassy itself. The building manager then spoke to the Libyan DCM to tell him that only the DCM could end the meeting and request the delegation to depart.

The DCM told the DS agent that the group was on a phone call and would then depart. The group remained boisterous throughout the call but then quieted down and left. The threat was made in the sixth floor elevator lobby.

Looks like this was handled correctly

And given our need for protection overseas, such an overt threat [even if said only in anger without real intent] has to be dealt with

Regards

Cheryl,

http://www.facebook.com/topic.php?uid=1243612375912588dopic=565

By the time I got up to speak, Jane Harmon and Christine Legarde had spoken a lot about me, them and women and there didn't seem to be much of an appetite in the audience for a serious speech--always a problem at these dinners--so I abbreviated Iran and Arab sections and skipped most of the section about women and made an appeal for the US still showing we can get things done keying off Fred Malik's opening comments. And I had dozens of people on the way out thank me and say how "inspirational" it was. Go figure.

Pis get me both a transcript of what I ended up saying and a copy of the campy film all the former Sec States made.

I met with Ambassador Gallegos this morning to inform him that he had been P&G'd as a reciprocal action for the unjustified expulsion of Amb Hodges.

We immediately reached out to the press to explain why we took this action. I also spoke to FM Maria Angela Holguin (Colombia) and FM Jose Antonio Garcia (Peru) to brief them on this step and encouraged them to reach-out to the Ecuadorans to ask them to refrain from escalating matters.

Holguin has a previously planned meeting in Quito next week-- and was going to speak to FM Patin° about that--she agreed to raise the issue. Garcia Belaunde will ask President Garcia to call Correa and advise him to moderate his statements and seek a constructive way forward.

Both will convey the message that the Ecuadorans cannot say, as they have in some of their comments, that "Ecuador has excellent relations with the United States," while taking the unwarranted step of expelling the US Ambassador.

Arturo

The folks from my office did tell me that the Secretary said during the town hall that cyber attacks and cyber intrusions comprise one of the biggest challenges and opportunities ahead today-- not surprising given her leadership in this area. I very much appreciate the priority she has given to these issues. If I don't get to tell her personally, I wanted to ask you to pass on to the Secretary, if appropriate, that its been a great pleasure, privilege and real honor to work for her. I know she probably, and deservedly, hears this all the time, but it has been the highlight of my career to work with her and I appreciate her support and vision. I also wanted to thank her for elevating cyber to a new foreign policy priority -- something many other countries are now emulating. Though I know I am but one in the multitude that feels this way, I will certainly miss her. I was a big fan before coming here and am doubly so now. Thanks to you too Cheryl for your help and support. I think we are on a good course now but there is much left to do and the challenges are great. I'm sure we will get a chance to chat when things calm down. Chris

Hi Mike,

One of the most important components of successful QDDR implementation (as with all policy goals) will be a strategic communications plan that supports it. In the run-up to the establishment of a formal QDDR Implementation office, we've worked within S/ES to pull together a shell of how to communicate internally to the Department featuring an intranet website which implementation leads would regularly update with status reports on the progress they're making (initial thoughts attached here from Sounding Board chief Kerry O'Connor). « Message: RE: QDDR Public Website »

In discussing this with Cheryl yesterday, Cheryl asked if you could please pull together an overarching strategic communications plan for both internally to the Department as well as externally that we'll feed to the QDDR office when it stands up (we hope soon).

I'd be happy to meet with you and your team to provide any additional background you need about the QDDR, but for your early information, I attach the memo the Secretary sent to the building on this in April.

Thanks,

Steve

Thanks Hillary and great announcement in Egypt on an economic agenda!

Quite a whirlwind since this email!

I was in Turkey doing govt/business/think tank meetings for a week, and was really struck by the effects rising food prices are having on all kinds of areas of life. Rising food prices also may cause a new look at Africa, given its potential for growth from that source; and given all the change in North Africa, I think Americans may be open to thinking about Africa in a new way. Pm going to try to write about this possible convergence of American interests and global trends. I know it's almost silly to raise these issues with you when you are literally juggling the world on your shoulders, but given your track record on the issues of food and Africa, thought it still worth it for down the road.

And of course, we'd still love to get you to CAP.

Thank you for all you're doing,

Neera

Hi Cheryl,

I thought that it might end up not being possible to have the chance to say hello today. Completely understandable. But sorry I missed you and I will look forward to whenever I see you in the future.

I should mention how much I love attending the Women of Courage Awards event. I think it is my favorite event to attend each year because it is so inspirational and, for me, energizing. Year after year the women who are celebrated are incredibly brave. It is a reminder of what the personal stakes are for real people in their own countries. And their illumination of unfathomable courage day-to-day distinguishes not only them but also this event in a meaningful way from a lot of things that I've attended over the years. So I must say thank you to the people in the State Department who let me attend this each year!

Take care Cheryl!

Cheers, Steve

Hi Cheryl,

First of all, thanks so much for convening the group to discuss our plans for the US Diplomacy Center.

I came away with the impression that everyone who attended felt that it would be an important part of the Secretary's legacy for the foreign service and for all those who work in the diplomatic arena.

We'll look forward to receiving some additional tweaks from S/P on the themes which will be incorporated into the exhibits, as well as to a communications strategy from Philippe.

In the meantime, when you speak to the Secretary about this, you might mention that Secy Jim Baker is very enthusiastic about the Center and has committed $1 million personally, $500,000 of which is already in hand, and has helped us with several companies and spoken personally to Henry Kissinger, who is also helping us. So it is a true bipartisan effort as well as a public/private partnership! Since we need them both on other issues like Law of the Sea, etc., it would be very awkward if we didn't finish the job.

Thanks again for your leadership and support, and I look forward to hearing from you soon.

Best,

Elizabeth

And I was proud to see a certain lady in light blue passing notes proving, yet again, the crucial role she has played in moving so many agendas forward in days that only had forty eight hours.

Madam Secretary,

Hope your trip is going well. Long but useful set of meetings in Kabul today, with side visit to FOB in Wardak. Look forward to discussing in more detail when I'm back, but a few impressions (within limits of this channel):

-- Very helpful for VP to get ground truths from variety of perspectives. He hadn't been here in two years.

-- Meeting with K (incl an hour one on one) was quite cordial. VP went out of way to accentuate positive, talked about strategic alignment between us on 2014, need to manage tactical differences better (PSCs, etc). K in "up" mood.

-- VP made public comment afterward about "not leaving in 2014 and staying as long as Afghans want us to." He meant enduring strat partnership, not continued combat role, but press already (hot surprisingly) contrasting this to earlier "we'll be out lock stock and barrel."

more details on another line, but nothing earth-shattering. All best, Bill

Thanks, Wendy.

This may seem a bit counterintuitive, but in some respects we're a bit ahead of pace (and in others respects, slightly behind). With respect to scheduling courtesy visits, we've reached out to all Committee members to gauge their interest in a meeting. My suspicion is you're right -- they're all distracted by the debt talks and other associated issues. But the requests tend to spike once a hearing is scheduled, when there's more urgency from their perspective.

Where we're ahead of pace is the review of your nomination materials by Committee Counsels. In that sense, last week's cancelled recess bought us a couple of additional days. As you know, once that review is completed, we're all clear for scheduling a hearing date.

Committee leadership (Majority and Minority) know you're a top priority of the Secretary and the Department. I'm still confident you'll move through the Committee process in a fairly expedient manner. What is harder to gauge is what happens on the floor once your nomination is reported out. Whether we'll be able to resolve whatever issues might arise at that stage is difficult to discern. But I can assure you, we'll pull out all the stops.

And rest assured, while there are other nominees, we play favorites. You're at the top of our priority list. And that doesn't come from just me. Cheryl and of course the Secretary share that sentiment.

To Ambassadors and DCMs:

As you will have heard, the parties reached a deal in Honduras late Thursday night. In advance of more formal talking points, please draw on following points Tom did for the Secretary. Please underscore that the Honduran negotoiating teams did a superb job, supported by their leaders. We were pleased to work closely with them over the last two days.

Throughout the crisis we we worked closely with the OAS and friends in the region. Please encourage host govts to support the Honduran elections now that there is a Guaymuras agreement.

Also, please underscore that S played an active role from the very beginning, by her key role in helping launch the San Jose process, to meeting with and calling key leaders (including Zelaya and Micheletti more than once). She also took the risk of sending a team to Honduras against long odds this week.

Many thanks to all for your support throughout. Particular kudos and thanks for Amb. Llorens, DCM Henshaw and their excellent team for four months of skilled and tireless work. USOAS under Lew Amselem did an outstanding job as well. WHA/CEN under Chris Webster and DAS Bisa Williams -- worked round the clock producing huge amounts of excellent work. WHA Press devoted long and productive hours as well.

Of course, the work is not done. Implementation and preparation for elections will keep everyone busy. But all who contibuted to this success should take a moment to enjoy it.

Best,

ck

When Jared and I went to Syria, it was because we knew that Syrian society was growing increasingly young (population will double in 17 years) and digital and that this was going to create disruptions in society that we could potential harness for our purposes.

In what is the 1st of what I predict will be many interesting cases in the future, this past week a campaign went viral on Facebook in Syria (even though Facebook is outlawed in Syria it is widely accessed through proxies) showing teachers in Syria abusing their pupils. Thousands of Syrians made public their support on Facebook (the fact that people made their identities known is notable) for the campaign to remove these teachers, and the Ministry of Education intervened and fired the teachers.

This is the first known case of a successful social media campaign in Syria.

More will come. Alec

Hi all,

I wanted to update everyone on the progress of a policy speech Raj is going to deliver next Thursday, the 20th, on economic growth. He's delivering the speech here at the Ronald Reagan Building, during an event highlighting our history of public-private partnerships.

The speech will lay out the evolution of development assistance, its role in generating economic growth and how the development community now needs to adopt a much more private sector-oriented approach to development in the years ahead. It will also lay out a strong defense of foreign engagement and discuss how our foreign affairs budget helps produce economic activity and job growth here at home.

I expect to have a draft to share with you all in the next couple of days, but wanted to make sure you were aware this was coming up.

Looking forward to your comments, -Maany

On Tuesday morning the Senate will first have the cloture vote on the Cr. We will get cloture and then ask them to yield back time and vote on final passage of the Cr. We do expect them to yield back some time (how much is unclear) as the govt shut down will occur tues at midnight. Following disposal of the Cr, we will have the cloture vote on START. As we get a better sense on timing of the START cloture vote during the day on tues, I will be sure to let Huma and Lona know in case there is a chance you can come by. The vote on ratification will either be very late on wed or on thurs am, depending on whether the Republicans will yield back time.

Wyden is the only Dem expected to miss the ratification vote, but that doesn't change the number of Rs we need. Still need 9, as its 2/3rds of those present (that would be 66 if everyone except Wyden were there).

We are still working on a fairly complex missile defense amendment from Corker and McCain, but I am hopeful we can work something out short of yet another understanding in the Resolution of Ratification, which will put further pressure on the Russians to retaliate. So we are trying very hard to come up with a condition or non-binding declaration. Will keep you posted.

Finally, believe we are ready for the closed session - Feinstein, Kerry and Lugar are well briefed up.

I'm not sure how the Burr language may have changed (is it still distinct from the Rogers bill, and what's the status of that?), but can you try to get some clarity for us early on Mon? Would this require that S designate? And if so, is it constitutional? And is DiFi still offering her mandatory language on the Senate side, or was that amended, changing "shall" to "should"? Thx.

Hillary--

Karl remains confident he can deliver on his own. I will keep you informed. If you wish to make call anyway, let me know. We will get some TPs together for a call tomorrow morning just in case. RH

To All:

The de facto authorities' consultations continued today -- with government agencies, Congress and judicial branch. The meetings just wrapped up. Our sources tell us the process is moving forward and will result in a series of measures Mon-Wed: some govt resignations and replacements; possible announcement of Dec 2 or 3 for Congressional action on Z issue; M "step aside." We have reiterated that latter is crucial for our diplomacy to boost election support. The de factos say the M speech announcing that is being drafted.

De facto negotiators say the military played a useful role today in pushing the process forward.

Amb Llorens notes that while the de facto consultations may look like a stall, the tendency to seek this sort of buy-in is one reason Honduras historically has been more peaceful than its neighors. While our role on the most sensitive issue is not known outside of very few people, the impression is growing in the country and among careful observers in region that something is happening. Insulza told Arturo today that he wants to find a pragmatic way forward and could use a fig leaf. We hope to produce something more than that. Z's negotiators are aware something is moving and appear keen to get back in the game, but Z has them on a tight leash and refuses to play. If things go well in next few days, we will ask S should call Z to encourage him back to the table.

We are in constant touch with the de factos to help keep this on track. While most Hondurans want to move on, there is still a great deal of polarization that makes progress complicated.

Best,

ck

Dear Madame Secretary:

I hope you are well. I am very proud of your remarkable work. You may remember that during the Clinton Administration I was Under Secretary of State for Economic, Business, and Agricultural Affairs and I was the chief U.S. negotiator for the Kyoto Protocol. Todd Stern and Jonathan Pershing were key parts of my team.

I have been doing pro bono representation of a remarkable organization fronted by Jeff Horowitz, Avoided Deforestation Partners, which combines many of the country's major environmental groups with a number of large electric utility companies. We are dedicated to reducing the rate of global deforestation, which is a major contribution to greater gas emissions. Tropical forests are also crucial as habitats for a majority of the world's species, and poor people depend upon forests for their livelihood.

Our inspiration has been Wangari Maathai, with whom I worked daily. Her premature passing is a genuine tragedy. I know you share my admiration for her.

I am attaching a letter from me and Jeff Horowitz asking that you agree to do a short video for an event at the Durban COP, honoring Wangari and supporting forest preservation.

Thank you for your consideration.

Madame Secretary: Just a brief update. First your embassy team and young FSOs are responding heroically to the many challenges we confront in Christ Church. Every member of the dialogue and their family are accounted for. I made sure personally that all have replacement passports and return flights. There are now three unaccounted Americans in the city. We are working closely with government to get up to date and accurate information.

This is critical as already this is the worst disaster in NZ history. Over 500 buildings very badly damaged and probably over one hundred dead. Our search and rescue team are arriving on scene shortly. Am encouraging NZ to ask us for water purification as all systems are destroyed around city. Working with Ambassador Huebner to set up fund to help rebuild iconic church badly damaged in quake. Also promised NZ authorities that we will provide relevant lessons learned from Haiti. I know how overwhelming ME issues are but small gestures and steps in coming days will demonstrate our solidarity and cement new phase of our relationship. More soon Kurt

the injured DS officer. he is now well enough to talk. he doesnt want a visit but a check in call and asking him if he needs anything would be good. monica will remind you of this. Also heard from both the bush and reagan libraries over the last few days. neither wants to host the oscar exhibit after it leaves little rock so i think we will focus on making that exhibit amazing and i will explain situation to odlr. more later .

Deputy JSE Jean-Marie Guehenno just emailed to me the message below from UNSMIS, which it received from one contact in Al Meydan. UNSMIS indicated that the information is consistent with explosions and smoke the monitors are able to hear and see from their hotel, precisely in the direction of that area. They will have difficulty, however, getting a patrol into the area.

Guehenno said that this information, if true, is cause for great concern. He fears that the government will "try to restore its capacity to intimidate the population by conducting particularly brutal operations."

Members of the Coordination Committee in the neighbourhood of Al Meydan requested UNSMIS to dispatch observers to the area. According to the source, government forces are preparing "a massacre" in an area called Al Kaa.

The security forces are besieging the area and shooting with tanks and artillery; the Free Syrian Army is resisting as best as it can. Government forces are about to enter the area from two directions, from the al-Majeed mosque and from al-Doba mosque.

Many civilians are trapped; there is little food, medicine and blood. Many are wounded. A building with many civilians has just been attacked in al-Kaa Square.

4 women were elected to be members of parliament for the first time. As you remember (because you were an eloquent voice for them), women finally won the right to vote and stand for office in 2005, but failed to win seats in the two previous election cycles.

You know some of the women who won, including Rola Dashti, who was one of the women who got the Vital Voices award and had been part of the long-time struggle. I told Lissa. You might want to mention in your Barnard speech.

Recession-proof vacation ideas. Find free things to do in the U.S.

The Wikileaks documents can be cast as reflecting a positive light on the U.S. government and diplomacy. Your statement about how the documents underscored the Iranian nuclear threat is headed in the right direction.

1. The Wikileaks disclosure is the opposite of the Pentagon Papers. The Pentagon Papers provided evidence from an internal study conducted by the Department of Defense that the U.S. administration was not telling the truth about the Vietnam War. On the contrary, the Wikileaks papers prove that the U.S. government today has been telling the truth about the threats we face in the world. Our government is telling the truth.

2. The Wikileaks papers prove that American diplomats are hard at work at the difficult, often frustrating job of protecting and advancing our interests in the world. These documents are testimony to the diligence, intelligence and clear mindedness of our diplomats. Our diplomats are doing their work on the frontlines of national security.

We met several months after Secy Clinton moved into the position. I was the Coordinator for CT prior to Dan Benjamin. I am following up on a request from Gov Bill Richardson which went thru Ms Lauren Jiloty.

Gov Richardson would like to meet with Secy Clinton at a time convenient with her to discuss the delisting of the MEK from the Foreign Terror Organization list. There are several bipartisan supporting governors (Dean, Ridge) , intelligence (Hayden) justice (Mukasey, Freeh) military (Pace, Shelton) and others that would like to attend.

You should be aware that there is a good chance at the contact meeting in Turkey the TNC ambassador to the UAE, a man you have not yet met, whose name is Dr. Neydah, may tell you the TNC has reached an agreement with a US company. The company is a new one, Osprey, headed by former General David Grange, former head of Delta Force. Osprey will provide field medical help, military training, organize supplies, and logistics to the TNC. They are trainers and organizers, not fighters. Grange can train their forces and he has drawn up a plan for taking Tripoli similar to the plan he helped develop that was used by the first wave of Special Forces in the capture of Baghdad.

This is a private contract. It does not involve NATO. It puts Americans in a central role without being direct battle combatants. The TNC wants to demonstrate that they are pro-US. They see this as a significant way to do that. They are enthusiastic about this arrangement. They have held meetings with Grange in Geneva and Dubai this week, Tuesday and Wednesday, that concluded late last night (Wednesday). They have developed a good relationship. This is the group the TNC wants to work with. As I understand it, they are still working out funding, which is related to the overall TNC funding problems.

Grange is very low key, wishes to avoid publicity and work quietly, unlike other publicity hungry firms. Grange is under the radar.

We have a readout of the Tantawi meeting with the political parties from a participant. . The group will reconvene on Thursday mid-day. Tantawi called in about 15-18 political party figures, to focus on the constituent assembly. SCAF told those gathered it was important to move beyond the crisis, start a dialogue and show Egyptians they can find a solution. The SCAF was politely showing the FJP that it had gone too far. Liberals complained they had been shut out of the process. In the end, it seemed as if the FJP was looking at what they might do to allay fears about the constitution. The elections for the constitutional assembly were over, so there was no going back on that. But options on the table — which we have heard from other liberals — would be endorsing a "bill of rights" to be incorporated into the constitution. Participants seemed pleased that the SCAF was playing a positive role. More meetings to follow.

Another idea is taking shape of the idea of a trip for a broad group of parliamentary leaders to the US in a "getting to know you" visit. We will pursue that.

I thought I would share this heartfelt message from Patricia Lamego de Teixeira Soares, the head of Brazil's Central Authority, the office responsible for Hague Convention abduction cases. You will see that in spite of our efforts to protect the son, the Brazilian family chose to make a spectacle outside the Consulate this morning by parading Sean through a crowd. Ms. Lamego recently visited the U.S. where she met with members of Congress and others to explain all that the Brazilian Central Authority was doing to reunite Sean and his father under the Hague Convention. The delays we saw in this case were largely the result of a wealthy, well connected family able to influence court decisions.

We are all relieved and thrilled to see this long overdue but very happy ending. I should also highlight the amazing work done by US Mission Brazil. The consular staff, Charge, Acting DCM (Marie Damour, the Consul General in Brasilia), LegATT, RSO, and a host of others all played a role in this successful return. My OCS DAS, Michele Bond, and her dedicated team also played a big role in communicating with David, his lawyers, Congress, and the press. We had Members of Congress, former Assistant Secretaries and US Ambassadors all pitching in. While there were disagreements at times over tactics, we all agreed that we were working towards the same goal: the safe return of Sean.

We particularly appreciate the strong support from the Secretary. Many people will try to take credit for today's happy reunion but it was the Secretary's continued concern and interest in this case that made the difference. We could not have provided a better gift to David Goldman during this season of giving. Janice

There are a number of different possibilities for how the decision on the Guinea/Madagascar credentials may go tomorrow. (It is Zambia and Tanzania bringing the challenge on behalf of the AU.) I was under the impression that we would not have to vote on the potential credentials challenges. We may have to.

We may have to vote on a motion to *deny* them credentials and exclude them. For the moment, the guidance is to vote to credential all countries — including these two — as is customary, while conducting outreach with Tanzania, Zambia, and the AU to explain that we have our own imperatives but we support the fact that they are taking a principled stand.

We may have to vote on a motion to *defer* decision, which would allow them to be seated and vote but would not formally grant credentials. For the moment, the guidance is to potentially support such a motion — this was the practice with respect to South Africa between 1983 and 1994. Everyone is in the same place on this.

Ultimately, however, the whole thing may die of its own weight. This is probably the most likely outcome.

Jake, I understand that S is meeting with Japanese FM Maehara tomorrow, and wanted to make you aware of news reports today indicating that Japan plans to announce shortly its intention to run for a UN Security Council seat for 2012-2013. Having just left the Council after a 2009-2010 term, this would be the earliest opportunity for Japan to seek another seat, and likely represents a strategy of seeking frequent election to a nonpermanent UNSC seat to bolster Japan's credibility in its pursuit of permanent Security Council membership. To date, Fiji, Kyrgyzstan, and Pakistan have announced their candidacy for a single Asia Group seat up in 2012. Japan has served ten times on the Council, tied for the most with Brazil. Esther

Rough meeting today, as you can see from the press work below, which Graham intended to be a tough message. I will do a report when I can. Much of the discussion was about the SPD in now familiar terms, with Graham getting emotional at times and all (McC, Graham, Sessions, Hoeven and Blumenthal) pressing K, McCain intervening at several points to calm Graham down. Graham told K flatly no SPD without process solutions on detentions and night raids; if that's not what he can accept, Americans will not support and he can forget it. K was obstinate and offensive, if calm, blaming the conflict on the US and twice describing US as occupiers— right after saying he is committed to the partnership. At one point he let slip that "the country that the US wants as an Ally must be sovereign." He also said that he is opposed to an Afghan detentions regime, and acknowledged that he had blocked what we regard as solutions on the legal framework for detentions, implying he would do so again. By the end Graham was fuming — and made a personal plea to K to do the right thing for the Afghan people. Noting K's repeated assertions that he wants the partnership, McCain observed that those who want an agreement usually find a way to get it and thought the message to K from his best friends in Congress would be useful, he'd need time to process. Wardak (not present) wants to get together on detentions tomorrow or Tuesday.

But the same argument of unfair pricing is made against all online content sellers, Apple as much as anyone. So that would argue against using any kind of eReader at all. I get the idea that these companies squeeze independent booksellers - but it's not like State currently buys 10,000 books from the local store to put in our 3rd floor library and is replacing that purchase with books from the new Amazon mega store up the block (hypothetical, doesn't exist). This isn't a Wal Mart situation. State most likely already buys books bulk, so this program simply shifts our purchasing from one mammoth company to another. Not to mention that the USG has a different responsibility than the average consumer to obtain the best value possible. Bookstores are definitely in trouble. But because of the technology itself, not Amazon's or Apple's business practices - which certainly compound the problem, but doesn't create it. Al Gore did when he invented the Interwebs.

I wanted to share with you a situation that recently has arisen in the event that it comes up during the FY 2012 Budget Hearings.

The USAID Office of the Inspector General (OIG) recently has completed a review of our Afghanistan Bank Supervision assistance activities. The OIG is set to release its report soon, probably next week.

However, I have been informed that the. Washington Post plans to publish an article on the OIG review of the USAID contractor advising the Afghan Central Bank on bank supervision - Deloitte Touche LLP. The article may appear in the March 13th Sunday edition. Deloitte trains Afghan bank examiners as part of its larger contract implementing our Economic Growth and Governance Initiative, which provides broad policy advice to the Afghan government.

I support the independence of our OIG and the audit community. They represent a vital check on all USG activities both home and abroad. As Administrator, I have made it a central goal to improve oversight of all USAID activities world-wide. I have directed the implementation of the Accountable Assistance for Afghanistan Initiative in order to ensure more stringent control and oversight of USG funds.

I am gravely concerned about the findings of the USAID/OIG and have directed our General Counsel to work closely with the USAID Mission to determine the appropriate course of action. I will keep you updated on this and as we move our assistance program in Afghanistan toward transition goals.

Shannon Darcy Sr. Development Advisor Office of the Special Representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan U.S. Department of State (202) 647-9403 (direct) (202) 647-9004 (main)

British intelligence believes that when the rebels recapture Ras Lanuf and other towns they will find evidence of atrocities committed by Libyan troops against the local population. Teammates -- As I leave Haiti today and turn over command of JTF-H to MG Sim Trombitas, I wanted to say thanks and express my deepest appreciation for all that each of you have done for the people of Haiti.

I have had the honor and privilege of working side by side with all our U.S. Military services; Ambassador Ken Merten and the US Embassy team; USAID's Office of Response Coordination led initially by Ambassador Lew Lucke and now by Chris Milligan; the UN Peace Keeping Forces from 18 nations led by Brazilian Major General Floriano Peixoto and now MG Paul Cruz; hundreds of non-governmental organizations (NG0s) like the Jenkins-Penn Haiti Relief Organization (VP HRO) led by Sean Penn; the Government of Haiti leaders from President Preval, Prime Minister Bellerive, to all his Ministers; and numerous community leaders in displaced persons camps and local Mayors. I believe no one can come to Haiti and leave unchanged. I know I have certainly been personally and professionally affected by what I have seen and experienced since 12 January 2010.

I can't help but look back to that January day when life seemed to stop. I saw death, suffering, pain, sadness and fear. I saw things that I will never forget. Today, I see courage, resiliency, and determination. I see it in the camps and in the markets. I see it in the faces of the vendors selling mangos. I see it in the artists who show off their paintings to passersby. And I see it in Haiti's leaders, with whom I met regularly. I see hope all around Haiti. .

All,

The President of the General Assembly (PGA) just announced the results of the first round of voting. Countries need to receive votes from at least 2/3 of the UN Member States present and voting in the General Assembly to win a seat. All 193 UN Member States were present and voting, so 129 is the required to win seat.

African Group (2 seats) • Mauritania 98 (proceeding to 2"d round) • Morocco 151 [ELECTED] • Togo 119 (proceeding to 2"d round)

Asian Group (1 seat) • Kyrgyzstan 55 • Pakistan 129 [ELECTED] (NOTE: Minimum # of votes needed) • Fiji 1— previously announced candidacy, but then rescinded

Eastern European Group (one seat) • Azerbaijan 74 (proceeding to 2' round) • Hungary 52 • Slovenia 67 (proceeding to 2nd round)

Group of Latin American and Caribbean States (1 seat) • Guatemala 191 [ELECTED] (2 abstentions)

The 2"d round (and 3rd rounds) of voting are restricted to the top two (in the case of 1 avail seat) vote recipients in the first round. The Eastern European Group will go to a rd round of voting, with Slovenia and Azerbaijan on the ballot. The African Group will go to the 2"d round as well, with Mauritania and Togo on the ballot.

The 2nd round of voting is starting now.

Dan

Sandy's email is down temporarily. He asked that I forward the following to you:

The domestic firestorm would be the same, regardless of the language. Congress will not parse the words; they will take the view that this is throwing Israel overboard. D's as well as R's. That will have consequences for the generally bipartisan support of our handling of Egypt, and put the Administration on the defensive. It will be seen as backtracking on our position—restated as recently as last week by Jim—that the UNSC is not the place to litigate these issues.

Undoubtedly, vetoing a resolution that echoes US policy hurts our credibility in the region and undercuts the forward-leaning posture we have cultivated over the past three weeks. That could feed the anti-American currents and manifest itself on the streets of Ramallah or elsewhere.

Obviously, better if we can get the Pals to withdraw, including holding out the prospect of putting forward TORs for negotiations. But if that is not successful, I come down—narrowly--on the side of veto. I know what happens here if we abstain; I am not sure what happens in the region if we veto.

If that is where you come out, it may be better not to change the language. And we certainly should try to get something from Bibi—on the g round or in his negotiating positions.

-Sandy

From our team in Cairo at the Opposition meeting, final session:

After about five hours the group agreed on a composition of the "follow up and communications committee." They will propose to their political bodies that it be a 21-person committee with three seats for the SNC; 2 seats for the KNC; and one seat for the other 16 groups.

This odd formulation was a result of the SNC's need to be perceived as the heavy weight and the Kurdish demand that it have more seats than the Turkmen. Despite getting their wish, the Kurds attempted (right before the vote) to add another seat in their umbrella which angered every participant in the room. Finally, after an Amb Ford scolding, they conceded.

Three people were selected to collect the names from each of the 18 groups. They are scheduled to submit the names of each group's participants to the Arab League in seven days.

Jake- Interesting report. Gene is closer to the action and I defer to him on the latest Jail-ian thinking and machinations vis-a-vis the cabinet and INC. I hadn't heard about ENI-related corruption but wouldn't be surprised.

On the federalism issue,. Jail is right to be concerned about eastern agitation for autonomy. A cabinet chance won't solve that problem, though. Nor will recruiting Belhaj and Islamist fighters to take on the Bardans. To the contrary, it would only lead to unwanted bloodshed - the large Obeid tribe still nurses a serious grudge against Belhaj and his ilk for the Islamists' presumed role in killing their beloved Gen. Yunis last July and would probably put up a fierce fight.

The cabinet and INC need to have a serious discussion with the Bargans - if they aren't already doing so - about how power and resources are to be distributed in the new Libya. The Libyans held similarly heated debates on this very topic in the early1950s as they held their first parliamentary elections and drafted their constitution (there were actually violent skirmishes in connection with those elections, and Washington delayed the arrival of the first US ambassador until after things had calmed down). Hopefully the current leadership can negotiate these issues peaceably in the corning months. Of course, we and the UN and our other partners should encourage them to do so.

- Chris

Good Morning Everyone. Or as they say here in Israel, 'Boker Toy'

Today's a special day, not simply because the trip is almost over, but because some of us are at home among our people. In honor of that, Pam has graciously allowed me to collaborate on today's daily missive. But don't worry, by popular demand she will resume the practice starting tomorrow - even though we'll be in Washington.

Today's isn't a quote per se, and it isn't anyone famoys. These traditional questions have been asked by Jewish children for millenia. They don't necessarily have answers tough, they are merely meant to encourage children to be inquisitive.

But I am attributing the below to one very special Jewish child who I know will go on to practice and further our rich traditions:

1) Ma nishtana ha-laila ha-zeh mi-kol ha-lelot? [Why is this stop different from all other stops?]

2) She-be-chol ha-lelot anu ochlin chametz u-matza, ha-laila ha-zeh kulo matza? [Why is it that on all other nights during the year we eat well-balanced, nutritional meals with vegetables, but on this trip we eat 5000 calorie meals mixing meats and cheeses and sauces that shouldn't be combined?]

3) She-be-chol ha-lelot en anu matbilin afilu pa'am echat, ha-laila ha-zeh shetay fe'amim? [Why is it on all other nights we do not eat ice cream dipped and fried even once, but on this trip we eat ice cream that has been dipped in artery clogging batter twice?]

4) She-be-chol ha-lelot anu ochlin bayn yoshvin u-vayn mseubin, ha-laila ha-zeh kelanu mesubin? [Why is it that on all other nights we eat either sitting or reclining, but on this trip we are admonished to eat in strapped to our seats in because we are within 200 minutes of landing?]

Colleagues
